It shall be unlawful for any solicitor of subscriptions to publications to solicit or take a subscription to any magazine, journal, periodical, or other publication of any kind within the city without first having registered such business with the city and paid the required regulatory fee. The business registration form shall specify the name of the individual authorized to solicit subscriptions within the city. (Prior Code, § 29-6) Sec. 12-168. - Exemptions. (a) Sales of items as a part of a garage sale, when the seller is a resident of the city, or in a duly registered flea market, or when the net proceeds of such sales are to be used by any county school or school organization or for any other charitable purpose, shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. Solicitation and the taking of subscriptions to publications shall also be exempt from the provisions of this article when the solicitor's earnings from such subscriptions are to be used by any county school or school organization, or for any other charitable purpose. (b) Blind persons, disabled veterans, and veterans having a physical disability incurred during service in the armed forces of the United States may peddle or conduct business in the city without paying an occupation tax or regulatory fee, subject to the limitations set forth in O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq.; provided that, before any such person may peddle or transact business without a license in the city without paying an occupation tax or regulatory fee, such person must furnish the secretary to the city commission with evidence of his/her right to such exemption as provided by O.C.G.A. § 43-12-2. (Prior Code, § 29-7) Sec. 12-169. - Registrations not transferable. No business registration or regulatory fee paid under the provisions of this article shall be transferable. (Prior Code, § 29-8) Sec. 12-170. - Written business registrations and criminal background check required. (a) All persons desiring to transact business in the city as a transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, or itinerant vendor of prepared foods under the provisions of this article shall submit to a criminal background check and file a written business registration, verified by affidavit and signed by the registrant, if an individual, by all partners, if a partnership, or by the president, if a corporation, with the secretary of the city commission, showing: (1) The name, date of birth, driver's license number, social security number, and description of the person who will conduct the registrant's business during the time that it is proposed to be carried on in the city, the name, date of birth, driver's license number, and social security number of all other persons who will participate in the transaction of business for the registrant in the city, the local address of such persons while engaged in such business, the permanent address of such persons, the fingerprints of such persons, the capacity in which such persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise), the name and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if any, and if a corporation, the state in which it was incorporated; (2) The place in the city where such person proposes to conduct the registrant's business, and the length of time for which it is proposed that such business be conducted; (3) A statement of the nature, character, and quality of the goods, wares, or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the registrant in the city; whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from stock in possession and by sample, at auction, by direct sale or by taking orders for future delivery; and where the goods or the goods or property proposed to be sold are located at the time such registration is filed; (4) If the registrant is not the individual owner of the business registered, the credentials of the person for which the registrant proposes to do business, authorizing the registrant to act as such representative; (5) The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; and (6) A photograph of the registrant, showing his/her facial features as they appear at the time such registration is filed, which shall be a two-inch by two-inch picture showing the head and shoulders of the registrant in a clear and distinguishing manner. (b) Any person desiring to transact business in the city as a peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or solicitor of subscriptions to publications under the provisions of this article shall submit to a criminal background check and file a written business registration, signed by the registrant and verified by his/her affidavit, with the secretary of the city commission, showing the following: (1) The name, date of birth, driver's license number, social security number, fingerprints, and description of the registrant; (2) A photograph of the registrant, showing his/her facial features as they appear at the time such registration is filed, which shall be a two-inch by two-inch picture showing the head and shoulders of the registrant in a clear and distinguishing manner; (3) Permanent home address and full local address of the registrant; (4) A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods or services to be sold, or the publications for which subscriptions will be solicited; (5) If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; and (6) The length of time for which the right to do business is desired. (c) The city, after authorization to initiate a criminal background check by the applicant, shall complete such criminal background check within three business days of the date of written registration. (Prior Code, § 29-9) Sec. 12-171. - Conduct of business prior to completion of registration, criminal background check and payment of regulatory fee prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, itinerant vendor of prepared foods, peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or solicitor of subscriptions to publications to conduct any business within the city until the registration and criminal background check are completed and the appropriate regulatory fee is paid in full. (Prior Code, § 29-10) Sec. 12-172. - Leaving premises when requested. It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, itinerant vendor of prepared foods, peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or solicitor of subscriptions to publications, when requested to leave the premises of any property located within the city by the owner or an agent of the owner of such property, to remain on the premises. (Prior Code, § 29-11) Sec. 12-173. - No solicitation when posted. It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, itinerant vendor of prepared foods, peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or solicitor of subscriptions to publications to enter the premises of any property located within the city where a "No Solicitation" sign is posted. (Prior Code, § 29-12) Sec. 12-174. - Registration and photo identification to be displayed. When conducting any business in the city pursuant to this article, the transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, itinerant vendor of prepared foods, peddler, canvasser, solicitor, or solicitor of subscriptions to publications shall display at all times the appropriate city registration and photo identification. (Prior Code, § 29-13) Sec. 12-175. - Regulatory fees amount. The regulatory fees required by the provisions of this article shall be available on a fee schedule in the city clerk's office. (Prior Code, § 29-14) Sec. 12-176. - Permitting unregistered persons to conduct business on business premises of another prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit the parking area or lot of any shopping center or of any business establishment or any other part of the premises of any business establishment to be used by any peddler, transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor of prepared foods for the conducting of the such peddler's business, transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, or itinerant vendor of prepared foods for the conducting of the business of such peddler, transient merchant, itinerant mechant, itinerant vendor, or itinerant vendor of prepared foods unless such peddler, transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, or itinerant vendor of prepared foods has filed a business registration with the city and paid the required regulatory fee; provided that this shall not apply to any peddler, transient merchant, itinerant merchant, itinerant vendor, or itinerant vendor of prepared foods exempt from paying an occupation tax or regulatory fee as provided in section 12-168. (Prior Code, § 29-15) Sec. 12-177. - Conducting business on highways, city streets, and other municipal property prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct business in the right-of-way of any city street or other property of the city or on the right-of-way of any highway within the corporate limits of the city unless expressly authorized to do so by an ordinance of the city. (Prior Code, § 29-16) Sec. 12-178. - Punishment and penalties. A violation of this article shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 29-17) Sec. 12-179. - Definitions. Mobile food vehicle. A motorized vehicle which may upon issuance of a license by the city clerk and conformance with the regulations established by sections 12-179 through 12-185, may temporarily park in designated areas to engage in the service, sale, or distribution of ready to eat food or individual portion service to the general public directly from the vehicle. Temporary food establishment. A business establishment which may upon issuance of a license by the city clerk and conformance with the regulations established by sections 12-179 through 12-185 may temporarily set up in designated areas to engage in the service, sale, or distribution of ready to eat food or individual portion service to the general public. Vendor. The registered owner or the owner's agent or employee of a mobile food vehicle or temporary food establishment. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Sec. 12-180. - Scope. The provisions of sections 12-179 through 12-185 apply to mobile food vehicles or temporary food establishments engaged in the business of cooking, preparing, and distributing food or beverages with or without charge upon or in public and private restricted areas. The ordinance codified in sections 12-179 through 12-185 does not apply to vehicles which dispense food and that move from place to place and are stationary in the same location for no more than 15 minutes at a time, such as ice cream trucks or vendors which are permitted as part of a city event. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Sec. 12-181. - Permit required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person, including any religious, charitable, or nonprofit organization, to operate within the city a mobile food vehicle or temporary food establishment without having obtained from the city clerk a permit for that purpose. (b) A person desiring to operate a mobile food vehicle or temporary food establishment shall make written application for such permit to the city clerk. The application for a license shall be on forms provided by the city clerk and shall include the following: (1) Name, signature, phone number, email contact, and business address of the applicant. (2) A description of the preparation methods and food product offered for sale including the intended menu. (3) Copies of all necessary licenses or permits issued by the Habersham County Health Department. (4) Insurance coverage. a. Proof of general liability policy with limits of no less than $1,000.000.00 combined single limit coverage issued by an insurer licensed to do business in this state and which names the city as an additional insured. b. Mobile food vendors must provide proof of public liability and property damage motor vehicle policy with limits of no less than $1,000.000.00 issued by an insurer licensed to do business in this state. (5) All vendors receiving a permit under sections 12-179 through 12-185 shall pay the required fee as set by the city commission and shall also obtain a peddler's license on an annual basis. (6) The city clerk shall issue no more than five active permits for any given date. (7) A permit under sections 12-179 through 12-185 shall not be transferable from person to person. (8) A permit is valid for one designated spot at the Splash Park and shall not be transferred between vendors. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Sec. 12-182. - Regulations. (a) No vendor shall operate their business within areas of the city where the permit holder has not been authorized to operate. (b) Customers shall be provided with single service articles such as plastic utensils and paper plates and a waste container for their disposal. All food vendors shall offer a waste container for public use which the vendor shall empty at its own expense. All trash and garbage originating from the vendor shall be collected and disposed of off-site by the operators each day. Spills of food or food by-products shall be cleaned up, and no dumping of gray water on the streets is allowed. (c) Signage is only allowed when placed on the mobile food vehicle or vendor's booth. No separate freestanding signs are permitted. (d) A vendor shall not operate within 500 feet of any fair, festival, special event, or civic event that is licensed by the city unless the vendor has obtained permission from the event sponsor. (e) The issuance of a permit does not grant or entitle the vendor to the exclusive use of any parking space to the permit holder. (f) A vendor shall not operate on private property without first obtaining written consent from the private property owner. A private property owner shall not permit the use of his/her property until a special use permit has been obtained to allow for such use. (g) Any power required by a vendor shall be self-contained and shall not be drawn from the public right-of-way. No power cable or equipment shall be extended at or across any city street, alley or sidewalk. (h) Vendors shall only be allowed to operate in areas designated by the city. (i) Vendors shall only be allowed to operate during the hours that the Splash Park is in operation. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Sec. 12-183. - Enforcement. (a) Any permit holder in violation of any provision of sections 12-179 through 12-185 or any rules and regulations promulgated by the city shall be subject to a fine of $250.00 per day. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. (b) Once a permit has been issued it may be revoked, suspended or not renewed by the city clerk for failure to comply with the provisions of sections 12-179 through 12-185 and any rules or regulations promulgated by the city. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Sec. 12-184. - Repealer. All former ordinances or parts of ordinances conflicting or inconsistent with the provisions of sections 12-179 through 12-185 are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Sec. 12-185. - Severability. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of sections 12-179 through 12-185 is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, said portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of sections 12-179 through 12-185. (Ord. No. 06-14-01, 7-1-2014) Secs. 12-186—12-209. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - YARD SALES
Sec. 12-210. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Personal property means clothing and other property which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or members of his/her household and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. The term "personal property" does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. Yard sale means and shall include all general sales open to the public conducted from or on residential premises in any residential zone, as defined in appendix B to this Code, the zoning ordinance of the city, for the purpose of disposing of personal property, including, but not limited to, all sales entitled "garage," "lawn," "yard," "attic," "porch," "room," "backyard," "patio," or "rummage" sales. The term "yard sale" shall not include a situation where no more than five specific items are held out for sale and all advertisement of such sale specifically names those items to be sold. (Prior Code, § 25-1) Sec. 12-211. - Compliance required. No yard sale shall be conducted in the city at any time or place, by any person, or in any manner other than as provided by and in full compliance with this article. (Prior Code, § 25-2) Sec. 12-212. - Property other than personal not to be sold. It shall be unlawful for any individual to sell or offer for sale, under authority granted by this article, property other than personal property. (Prior Code, § 25-3) Sec. 12-213. - Combined sales. No more than four yard sales may be conducted at any location during any calendar year. If members of more than one household join in a yard sale, then such yard sale shall be considered as having been conducted at each and all of the residences of the persons conducting or participating in the sale. (Prior Code, § 25-4) Sec. 12-214. - Written notice required. Prior to conducting any yard sale, the individual proposing to conduct such sale shall file a written notice with the secretary of the city commission at least two days and not more than seven days in advance of the sale, setting forth the following information: (1) Names and addresses of all persons proposing to conduct or participate in the sale. (2) The location at which the proposed yard sale is to be held. (3) The date upon which the sale shall be held. (4) The dates within the current calendar year of any other yard sales conducted by or in which participated the person proposing to conduct or participate in the sale. (5) An affirmative statement that the property to be sold is and has been owned by the person proposing to conduct the sale as his/her own personal property, and was neither acquired or consigned for the purposes of resale. (Prior Code, § 25-5) Sec. 12-215. - Hours of sale. Yard sales shall be limited in time to no more than the daylight hours of three consecutive days. (Prior Code, § 25-6) Sec. 12-216. - Display of sale property. Personal property offered for sale at a yard sale may be displayed at any place on the premises of the residence where being conducted, but only on such premises. No property may be displayed for sale on a public right-of-way. (Prior Code, § 25-7) Sec. 12-217. - Advertising; signs. (a) Signs permitted. Only the following specified signs may be displayed in regard to a pending yard sale: (1) Two signs of not more than four square feet in area, to be displayed on the property of the residence where the yard sale is being conducted. (2) Directional signs of not more than two square feet in area each, provided that the premises upon which the yard sale is conducted is not on a major thoroughfare and that written permission to erect such signs is received from the property owners upon whose property such signs are to be placed. (b) Time limitations. No sign or other form of advertisement shall be exhibited for more than four days prior to the day such sale is to commence. (c) Removal of signs. All signs must be removed within 24 hours after the end of the yard sale. (Prior Code, § 25-8) Sec. 12-218. - Responsibility for good order and conduct. The owner and tenant, if any, of the premises on which a yard sale is conducted and all other persons named in the notice filed with the secretary of the city commission as proposing to conduct or participate in such yard sale shall obey the reasonable orders of any employee of the city in order to maintain the public health, safety and welfare. (Prior Code, § 25-9) Sec. 12-219. - Inspection. Any police officer of the city or any other employee of the city now or hereafter designated by any city ordinance shall have the right of entry to any premises showing evidence of a yard sale for the purpose of inspection and enforcement of the provisions of this article and may close the premises from such a sale where such sale is being conducted in violation of this article. (Prior Code, § 25-10) Sec. 12-220. - Parking. All parking of vehicles shall be conducted in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances and provisions of this Code. Furthermore, the police department may enforce such temporary controls as are necessary to alleviate any special hazards and/or congestion created by any yard sale. (Prior Code, § 25-11) Sec. 12-221. - False information. The giving of false information by any person in the written notice required by section 12-214 or to any police officer or other employee of the city concerning any yard sale is prohibited and shall be unlawful. (Prior Code, § 25-12) Sec. 12-222. - Exemptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following: (1) Any person selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. (2) Any person acting in accordance with his/her powers and duties as public officials. (3) Any bona fide charitable, eleemosynary, educational, cultural or governmental institution or organization, when the proceeds from the sale are used directly for the institution or organization's charitable purposes and the goods or articles are not sold on a consignment basis. (Prior Code, § 25-13) Sec. 12-223. - Separate violations. Every sale of an article of personal property and every day a sale is conducted in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. (Prior Code, § 25-14) Sec. 12-224. - Violation; penalty. A violation of this article shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 25-15) Secs. 12-225—12-250. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 12-251—12-274. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COMMERCIAL WASTEWATER PRETREATMENT
Sec. 12-275. - [Installation requirements.] Requirements for installation of a sand and oil/grease interceptor shall be as follows: (1) All users involved in the preparation of food for commercial purposes shall provide oil/grease interceptors or traps. Additionally, any user who generates wastewater which contains greater than the quantity of oil and grease regulated under section 12-276, and provided that the excess oil and grease is floatable and can be effectively removed in an oil/grease interceptor or trap, then said user will be required to install a grease/oil interceptor. (2) Under the sink grease trap interceptors must be approved by the pretreatment coordinator before installation and will be permitted under special circumstances only. (3) All users whose wastewater stream is associated with unusually large quantities of grit, sand or gravel shall be required to install a sand trap. All car/truck wash systems shall be required to install sand traps. (4) The requirements of this SUO section shall not apply to private living quarters or dwelling units. (5) New restaurants or food establishments must notify the city's pretreatment coordinator before opening their restaurant or establishment to be placed on the inspection list for grease trap maintenance. New restaurants and establishments will be given an estimated pumping rate based on the projected number of customers to be served and will be re-evaluated after one year. (Ord. No. 07-08-03, § 3.5, 8-5-2008) Sec. 12-276. - Design criteria. (a) Design criteria for required sand and oil/grease interceptors at restaurants and other eating establishments shall be as follows: (1) All interceptors shall have a capacity of 15 gallons per seat. (2) No grease trap shall be smaller than 1,500 gallons or larger than 3,000 gallons. All grease interceptors must have a basket strainer installed on the outlet end to the city's sewer system with a maximum of one-half inch allowable solids to pass through the strainer. (3) Grease trap interceptors must have two access manholes one on each side of the interceptor for clean out and maintenance purposes. The manholes shall have a minimum of one-inch rise above grade sloped to prevent stormwater from entering the grease trap interceptor. (b) Design criteria for required sand and oil/grease interceptors for establishments other than eating establishments shall be as follows: (1) All interceptors shall have a capacity that will provide not less than ten minutes, nor more than 30 minutes retention time at the peak eight-hour flow rate. (2) Flow through velocities shall not exceed one foot per second at the peak eight-hour flow rate. (Ord. No. 07-08-03, § 3.5, 8-5-2008) Sec. 12-277. - Maintenance. Maintenance requirements: (1) All grease, oil, and sand interceptors or traps shall be maintained by the user at the user's expense. The frequency of removal shall be such as to ensure that no overflows of oil, grease or sand into the wastewater system escape. The city reserves the right to increase the frequency of pumping if during an inspection of the grease interceptor the city deems it necessary to prevent fats, oils and grease from entering the city's sewer system. (2) All grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps shall provide continuous efficient operation. (3) Restaurants or food establishments must notify the city's pretreatment coordinator at least one hour in advance of the grease interceptor being pumped for inspection by a city employee. Failure to notify the city before pumping for inspection will be subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-12 of the Municipal Code. Grease interceptors must be pumped between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. Monday—Friday. The number to notify the city is (706) 778-6461. (4) Users shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material, and shall maintain records of the dates, means of disposal which are subject to review by the city. (5) Restaurants or food establishments who do not have their grease interceptor pumped within seven days of their last scheduled pumping will be subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-12 of the Municipal Code. (6) At a minimum, grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps shall be maintained at the following intervals: a. Monthly for establishments serving an average of 200 or more customers per day. b. Quarterly for establishments serving an average of 1—200 customers per day. (7) Within 30 days of a pumping or maintenance activity, each user shall submit records of proper maintenance and disposal of wastes to the city. The following information, as applicable, must be provided as a minimum. Failure to submit the following data may result in punishment under section 1-12 of the Municipal Code. (Ord. No. 07-08-03, § 3.5, 8-5-2008)

div.head: Chapter 14 - CABLE AND OTHER TELECOMMUNICATION SERVICES FRANCHISING[1]
Chapter 16 - CIVIL DEFENSE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 16-1. - Definition. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Civil defense means and shall include measures necessary to provide for the mobilization, organization and direction of civilian populace and necessary support agencies to prevent or minimize the effects of fire, flood, storm, earthquake and epidemic, as well as the effects of enemy or subversive activities, directed against the populace, communities, industrial plants, facilities and other installations of the city. (Prior Code, § 6-1) Sec. 16-2. - Council of defense—Created; membership. The city council of defense is hereby created and shall include the following: (1) The mayor; (2) The director of civil defense, as appointed; (3) The police chief; (4) The fire chief; (5) The city health officer; (6) The city manager; (7) The county or city welfare officer; (8) The American Red Cross representative; and (9) Others, including representatives of business, labor, civic and patriotic organizations as appointed by the council. (Prior Code, § 6-2) Sec. 16-3. - Same—Powers and duties. It shall be the duty of the city council of defense to: (1) Prepare a city civil defense plan, which shall provide for the effective mobilization of all the resources of the city, both private and public; (2) Prepare and recommend, for consideration by the city commission, an ordinance necessary to implement the civil defense plan; and (3) Consider and recommend to the city commission for approval mutual aid plans and agreements. (Prior Code, § 6-3) Sec. 16-4. - Civil defense director. (a) There is hereby created the office of the city civil defense director. Such officer shall be appointed by the mayor. (b) It shall be the duty of the civil defense director to: (1) Represent the mayor on all matters pertaining to civil defense; (2) Require and direct cooperation of city officials in the preparation and implementation of civil defense plans; (3) Direct, during periods of emergency, the services of any city officers or employees; and (4) Obtain, during periods of emergency, vital supplies and equipment lacking and needed for the protection of life and property of the people of the city, bind the city for the value thereof, and, if required immediately, requisition such supplies and equipment. (Prior Code, § 6-4) Sec. 16-5. - Civil defense corps—Composition. Officers and employees of the city with volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during an emergency and all groups, organizations and persons charged with duties necessary for the protection of the life and property in the city during such an emergency shall constitute the civil defense corps of the city. (Prior Code, § 6-5) Sec. 16-6. - Same—Divisions; division chiefs. (a) The functions and duties of the city civil defense corps shall be distributed among the following divisions: (1) Law enforcement division; (2) Fire services division; (3) Transportation division; (4) Medical and health division; (5) Communications division; (6) Welfare division; (7) Information and education division; and (8) Others as determined locally. (b) Each division shall be under the direction of a chief and deputy chief appointed by the council of defense. The chief of divisions will include public officials such as sheriffs, chiefs of police and fire departments, and heads of agencies dealing with transportation, communications, and other sundry services, as well as private businessmen who, through profession, knowledge and experience are particularly qualified to head divisions requiring specialized knowledge and experience. (Prior Code, § 6-6) Sec. 16-7. - Volunteers. Any person, other than an officer or employee of the city, volunteering his/her services to civil defense under the provisions of this chapter shall serve without compensation. While engaged in such service, such person shall have the same immunities as an employee of the city performing similar duties. (Prior Code, § 6-7) Sec. 16-8. - Fines and penalties. It shall be a violation of this chapter, punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, imprisonment for a period not to exceed 180 days, or both, to commit any of the following acts during an emergency: (1) Wilfully obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the civil defense corps in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him by virtue of this chapter. (2) Commit any act forbidden by any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this chapter, if such act is of such a nature as to give assistance to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of the city or prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof. (3) Wear, carry, or display, without authority, any mark or identification specified by the council of defense. (Prior Code, § 6-8)

div.head: Chapter 18 - CRIMINAL PROCEDURE AND OFFENSES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 18-1—18-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CRIMINAL PROCEDURE[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Bonds in cases of offenses against municipality, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-1 et seq.
Sec. 18-19. - Penalties. A violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. Sec. 18-20. - Bail; forfeiture of bond. (a) Any person arrested for an offense against an ordinance or law of the city or for such other offense as is, by general law, made subject to the jurisdiction of the municipal court may give bond with good security, conditioned for the appearance of such person at the municipal court to answer to the offense with which the person so arrested is charged. Such bond shall be in an amount not exceeding $1,000.00 and shall be made payable to the city. When any person who has given bail for his/her appearance shall fail to personally appear at the municipal court at the time fixed for his/her appearance to answer the offense with which he/she is charged, such person shall forfeit his/her bond. The judge shall order an execution hearing not sooner than 120 days but not later than 150 days after such failure to appear. Notice of the execution hearing shall be served within ten days of such failure to appear by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to the surety at the address listed on the bond or by personal service to the surety within ten days of such failure to appear at its home office or to its designated registered agent. Service shall be considered complete upon the mailing of such certified notice. If, at the execution hearing, it is determined that judgment should be entered, the judge shall so order, and a writ of fieri facias shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the court where such judgment is entered. (b) Any bond given by a witness or a prosecutor for his/her personal appearance at a designated time before the municipal court of the city shall, upon the failure of such witness or prosecutor to appear before such court at such designated time, be forfeited. (Prior Code, § 7-2) Sec. 18-21. - Forfeiture, cash bond. Any person charged with an offense against an ordinance or law of the city or with an offense made by general law subject to the jurisdiction of the municipal court who gives a cash bond for his/her personal appearance before the municipal court of the city to answer to the offense with which he/she is charged, any prosecutor who gives a cash bond for his/her personal appearance before the municipal court of the city to prosecute, or any witness who gives a cash bond for his/her personal appearance before the municipal court of the city to testify who fails to appear before such court when the case in which such person has made such bond to appear is called for trial shall forfeit such cash bond. It shall not be necessary for the city to take any further action to forfeit such cash bond, and such bond shall be paid into the general funds of the city. (Prior Code, § 7-4) Sec. 18-22. - Forfeiture no bar to subsequent prosecution. Forfeiture of any bond shall not be a bar to a subsequent prosecution of the accused for such violation. (Prior Code, § 7-5) Sec. 18-23. - Bench warrant. Upon the forfeiture of any bond under the provisions of this article, the judge shall have the authority to issue a bench warrant directing the chief of police of the city and all other police officers of the city to arrest the principal of such bond and bring such principal before the municipal court of the city for trial. Should it appear, however, that an offense against any criminal law of this state has been committed by the accused, the judge shall have authority to bind him/her over to the state court of the county for such action as may be legal and proper. (Prior Code, § 7-6) Secs. 18-24—18-49. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39; certain signs, devices, and structures prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-51 et seq.; more restrictive local laws regarding signs and signals authorized, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-97; jurisdiction to try and dispose of criminal cases of one ounce or less of marijuana, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-6; gambling, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-21; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; prohibition on consumption and possession of open alcoholic beverages in vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-253.
Sec. 18-50. - Disturbing the peace. It shall be unlawful for any two or more persons to assemble at any place within the corporate limits of the city and, by loud discourse, boisterous conduct, the sounding of one or more motor vehicle horns, or the operation of any other noise making device, disturb the public peace. (Prior Code, § 15-1) Sec. 18-51. - Unlawful assembly; failure to disperse. It shall be unlawful for any two or more persons, after having assembled on private property of any other person within the corporate limits of the city in the absence of and without first having obtained the permission of the owner, tenant in possession, or person in charge of such private property to assemble thereon, to fail to disperse and cease such assembly upon being directed to do so by any police officer of the city. (Prior Code, § 15-2) Sec. 18-52. - Dumping of trash on city property. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, dump, place or throw any garbage, trash, paper or filth of any kind in the city park or upon any city property within the corporate limits of the city. (Prior Code, § 15-3) State Law reference— Prohibition against public littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-43 et seq. Sec. 18-53. - Posting of signs, notices, advertisements, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to post, display or allow to remain posted or displayed any sign, advertisement, placecard, circular, notice or anything of similar nature in the city park or upon any tree, post, telephone pole, or anything of similar nature within the city park or upon any street, alley or road of the city without obtaining a permit. (Prior Code, § 15-4) State Law reference— Restrictions, limitations, violations for placing posters and signs on public and private property of posters, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-58. Sec. 18-54. - Hunting prohibited. It shall be unlawful to hunt or shoot squirrels or other wild game within the corporative limits of the city. (Prior Code, § 15-5) Sec. 18-55. - Unlawful use of loudspeakers. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to use or speak with any amplifier, mechanical loudspeaker, public address system, or any other device for the amplification of the human voice or of a musical recording upon any of the streets, alleys, or vacant property within the corporate limits of the city without first furnishing satisfactory proof to the city commission that the use of such amplifier, mechanical loudspeaker, public address system, or other device will not constitute a public nuisance and will not disturb the good order and quiet of the city and obtaining a written permit for the use of such equipment from either the city commission or the city manager. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to use or speak with any amplifier, mechanical loudspeaker, public address system, or any other device for the amplification of the human voice or a musical recording upon public or private property within the corporate limits of the city in such manner as to disturb the peace and tranquility of or invade the privacy of the home or place of business of any other person or of any place of public gathering, or to interfere with the use and enjoyment of public property or property owned or occupied by others in the city without first obtaining a written permit. (Prior Code, § 15-6) State Law reference— Conditions under which sounds from motor vehicle audible at a distance of 100 feet or more prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14. Sec. 18-56. - Disorderly conduct. (a) Any person who shall commit any of the following acts shall be guilty of the offense of disorderly conduct: (1) Using any vulgar, indecent or profane language on any street, road, lane or alley or at any public place within the city, using any abusive, insulting, offensive, obscene, opprobrious or threatening language to anyone or otherwise acting in any disorderly manner within the corporate limits of the city, or doing any act or using any language or words within the corporate limits of the city which tends to disturb the peace or endanger the morals, safety or health of the citizens of the city. (2) Committing any act within the corporate limits of the city against the public safety, morality or decency. (3) Being and appearing in an intoxicated condition on any public street, lane, alley, or highway, within the curtilage of any private residence not in the exclusive possession of the person so intoxicated, upon any railway passenger train or other public conveyance, or upon any fair grounds, ball grounds, show grounds or any other place of public gathering or assembly which said drunkenness is caused by the excessive use of intoxicating wines, beers, homebrew, liquors, or any other intoxicating beverage or drugs. (4) Being in a drunken or intoxicated condition within the curtilage of his/her own home and acting in such a disorderly, loud or violent manner as to disturb other citizens of the city or in such manner as to disturb the good order, peace and welfare of the city. (5) Throwing or placing any beer cans, liquor bottles, glass bottles or containers, cans, or trash or debris in any public street or highway in the city, in the city park, or on any premises in the city not in the possession of such person or without the consent of the owner and person in possession of same. (6) Rolling dice, playing with playing cards, or engaging in any other conduct usually associated with gambling on any public street, road, highway, alley or sidewalk in the city. (7) Obstructing, alone or with others, any public street, road, highway, alley or sidewalk in the city by hindering or impeding the free and uninterrupted movement of vehicles or pedestrians thereon. (8) Committing, in or upon any public street, road, highway, alley, sidewalk or other place or building in the city, any act or thing which is an obstruction of or interference with the free and uninterrupted use of property or any business lawfully conducted by anyone in, upon, or facing or fronting on such public street, road, highway, alley, sidewalk or other place or building, which obstruction or interference prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress, and regress therein, thereon, thereto or therefrom. (b) Any person found guilty of any act of disorderly conduct as described in subsection (a) of this section shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 15-8) Sec. 18-57. - Prohibited conduct in parking areas. (a) Motor vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person, while on or in any parking area or lot or any other part of the premises of any shopping center or other business establishment providing parking for its patrons, to race the motor of any motor vehicle, cause the wheels of any motor vehicle to spin, to stop any motor vehicle in such a manner as to cause its tires to slide or skid on the surface of such parking area or lot or other part of such premises, or to cause to be made any loud or unseemly noise which disturbs the peace and tranquility of the city. (b) Alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink beer, wine, intoxicating liquor, or any other alcoholic beverage while on the parking area or lot of any shopping center or other business establishment providing parking for its patrons. (c) Loitering. It shall be unlawful for a group of three or more persons to congregate and linger at any location on the parking area or lot or any approaches thereto or on any other part of the premises of any shopping center or other business establishment providing parking for its patrons. (d) Cruising. No person shall cruise in a motor vehicle in or drive a motor vehicle on, onto, or from the parking area or lot or any other part of the premises of any shopping center or other business establishment providing parking for patrons during the hours when the businesses located in such shopping center are closed or during the hours when such other business establishment is closed for doing business with its patrons. This prohibition shall not apply to owners and employees of such businesses while going to or leaving work or otherwise performing duties connected with such businesses. (e) Leaving vehicle unoccupied. It shall be unlawful for any person to park and leave or cause to be parked and left unoccupied any motor vehicle on any parking area or lot or any other part of the premises of any shopping center or other business establishment providing parking for its patrons except with the knowledge and consent of the operator of the business whose patrons are served by the area where such motor vehicle is so parked and left unoccupied or with the knowledge and consent of the person in charge of the area where such vehicle is so parked and left unoccupied. (Prior Code, § 15-9) Sec. 18-58. - Duty to erect warning sign. It shall be the duty of the owner or lessee of the parking area or lot of every shopping center and of every other business establishment providing a parking area for its patrons of sufficient size to encourage loitering or cruising in motor vehicles in such area to post on or immediately adjacent to such parking lot or area, in a conspicuous location, one or more signs bearing the following legend: Customer Parking Only Parking for other purposes, cruising in motor vehicles, and congregating and lingering in this parking area are prohibited. (Prior Code, § 15-10) Sec. 18-59. - Possession of marijuana. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess one ounce or less of marijuana within the corporate limits of the city. (Prior Code, § 15-11) Sec. 18-60. - Blocking of railroad grade crossings. It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, locomotive engineer, conductor, flagman, brakeman or any other person to block or cause to be blocked the railroad grade crossings on Main Street or First Street in the city with a locomotive, a freight or passenger car, a train or any part thereof, or any other kind of railroad equipment so as to prevent motor vehicles from being driven across the railroad at such railroad grade crossings on either of such streets for a period of time exceeding five minutes. When either of such railroad grade crossings has been cleared after having been so blocked, it shall be unlawful for any railroad company, locomotive engineer, conductor, flagman, brakeman or any other person to block or cause to be blocked such grade crossings with a locomotive, with freight or passenger cars, with a train or any part thereof, or with any other kind of railroad equipment prior to the expiration of a period of five minutes immediately following such clearing of such grade crossing except as provided by law. (Prior Code, § 15-12) Sec. 18-61. - Violation and penalty. A violation of this article shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 15-13) Sec. 18-62. - Criminal trespass by motor vehicle; penalty. (a) A person commits the offense of criminal trespass by a motor vehicle when the person, after having been requested not to do so by a law enforcement officer or by the owner or an authorized agent of the owner, parks or stands an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in or repeatedly drives a motor vehicle through or within a parking area located on privately owned property and provided by a merchant, a group of merchants, or a shopping center or other similar facility for customers thereof if: (1) The parking area is identified by at least one sign, as specified in this subsection, or, if the parking area contains more than 150 parking spaces, by at least one such sign for every 150 parking spaces, each such sign containing the following information in easy-to-read printing: a. Notice of the elements of the crime of criminal trespass by motor vehicle; b. Identification of the property which is reserved for customers' use only; c. Identification of the merchant, group of merchants, shopping center or other similar facility providing the parking area; and d. Warning that violators will be prosecuted. (2) The motor vehicle is parked, is standing, or is being operated other than for the purpose of: a. Transporting some person to or from the interior of the place of business of a merchant identified by the sign or signs in the parking area or to or from the interior of the shopping center or other facility so identified; b. Making use of a telephone, vending machine, automatic teller machine, or other similar facility located in the parking area; c. Meeting the requirements of a situation in which it has unexpectedly become impossible or impractical for the motor vehicle to continue to travel on the public roads; or d. Carrying out an activity for which express permission has been given by the owner of the parking area or an authorized representative of the owner. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to commit the offense of criminal trespass by a motor vehicle within the corporate limits of the city, and, notwithstanding the provision of section 18-61, any person who commits the offense of criminal trespass by motor vehicle shall be subject to a monetary fine. (Prior Code, § 15-14) Sec. 18-63. - Discharging firearms within the city limits. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to fire, shoot off or discharge a firearm within the city. The provisions of this section shall not apply to: (1) Persons who shall fire, shoot off or discharge a firearm in defense of person or property; (2) Law enforcement officers; and (3) Persons who shall fire, shoot off or discharge a firearm at a firing range approved by the police chief of the city and which is supervised by law enforcement officers or representatives of a local, state or national gun club. (b) Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section, shall on conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed in section 1-12 of this Code. (Ord. No. 11-12-01, § 1, 12-4-2012) Secs. 18-64—18-82. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - MINORS
Sec. 18-83. - Purpose and intent. Inasmuch as: (1) In the city as elsewhere there have been many instances of diminished parental discipline and ineffective control and guidance of children resulting in an increase in violent acts by children, truancy, and a rapid development of youth gangs, all attributable in large measure to deterioration of family values; and (2) Experience has clearly demonstrated that violent acts of children, truancy, and rapid expansion of youth gang membership result to a large degree from the freedom with which children are allowed to be away from home without parental supervision during times traditionally recognized to be those when they should be under the supervision and control of the persons having their custody; and (3) It has been established elsewhere that these conditions can be relieved and in a measure prevented by the use of a youth curfew, with parents and other persons having custody being encouraged to cooperate therewith and increase guidance and control of their children, strengthening parental discipline and reinforcing family bonds; therefore: The objective, purpose and intent of this article is to precipitate improved supervision and guidance of children, reverse the deterioration of family values, and strengthen family bonds in order to reduce juvenile delinquency, achieve decreased numbers of violent acts of children, reduce truancy, deter the development and growth of youth gangs, and ultimately improve the health and morals of the persons affected hereby, with the result being improvement in the safety and well being of all citizens of the city. (Prior Code, § 39-1) Sec. 18-84. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Minor means any person under 18 years of age. (Prior Code, § 39-2) Sec. 18-85. - Curfew. It shall be unlawful for any minor to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon any public street, highway, road, lane, park, playground or other public ground, public place, public building, place of amusement, eating place, vacant lot or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays, the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day. The provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: (1) When a minor is accompanied by his/her parent, guardian, or other adult person having lawful care and custody of the minor; (2) When the minor is on an emergency errand for his/her parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; (3) When the minor is returning directly home from a school or church activity; (4) When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in such places during the prescribed period of time; (5) When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from any activity involving the exercise of first amendment rights of freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; (6) When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel, with interstate travel through the city excepted in all cases from the curfew; and (7) When the minor is on the property of or the sidewalk directly adjacent to the building in which he/she resides. (Prior Code, § 39-2) Sec. 18-86. - Responsibility of parents, guardians, etc. All parents, guardians and other adult persons having lawful custody of minors shall make the provisions of this article known to their children or wards, and it shall be unlawful for any such parent, guardian, or other adult person having lawful custody of a minor to fail to do this or to permit or by inefficient control allow a violation of this article by a minor in his/her custody. (Prior Code, § 39-3) Sec. 18-87. - Violation and penalty. A violation of this article shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 39-4)

div.head: Chapter 20 - ENVIRONMENT
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 20-1—20-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-18-02, §§ I—X, adopted Aug. 7, 2018, repealed the former Art. II., §§ 20-19—20-26, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Prior Code, §§ 23-2—23-9. State Law reference— Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq.
Sec. 20-19. - Title. This ordinance [from which this article derived] will be known as "Soil Erosion, Sedimentation and Pollution Control Ordinance." (Ord. No. 07-18-02, § I, 8-7-2018) Sec. 20-20. - Definitions. The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise specifically stated: Best management practices or BMPs includes sound conservation and engineering practices to prevent and minimize erosion and resultant sedimentation, which are consistent with, and no less stringent than, those practices contained in the 'Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia' published by the commission as of January 1 of the year in which the land disturbing activity was permitted. Board means the board of natural resources. Buffer means the area of land immediately adjacent to the banks of state waters in its natural state of vegetation, which facilitates the protection of water quality and aquatic habitat. Certified personnel means a person who has successfully completed the appropriate certification course approved by the Georgia Soil and Water Conservation Commission. Coastal marshlands shall have the same meaning as in O.C.G.A. § 12-5-282. Commission means the Georgia Soil and Water Conservation Commission (GSWCC). CPESC means certified professional in erosion and sediment control with current certification by EnviroCert, Inc., which is also referred to as CPESC or CPESC, Inc. Cut means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavation; the depth below original ground surface to the excavated surface. Also known as excavation. Department means the Georgia Department of Natural Resources (DNR). Design professional means professional licensed by the State of Georgia in the field of: engineering, architecture, landscape architecture, forestry, geology, or land surveying; or a person that is a certified professional in erosion and sediment control (CPESC) with a current certification by EnviroCert, Inc. Design Professionals shall practice in a manner that complies with applicable Georgia law governing professional licensure. Director means the director of the environmental protection division or an authorized representative. District means the soil and water conservation district. Division means the environmental protection division (EPD) of the department of natural resources. Drainage structure means a device composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic or other such material that conveys water from one place to another by intercepting the flow and carrying it to a release point for storm water management, drainage control, or flood control purposes. Erosion means the process by which land surface is worn away by the action of wind, water, ice or gravity. Erosion, sedimentation and pollution control plan means a plan required by the Erosion and Sedimentation Act, O.C.G.A. ch. 12-7, that includes, as a minimum protections at least as stringent as the state general permit, best management practices, and requirements in section 20-22(c) of this article. Fill means a portion of land surface to which soil or other solid material has been added; the depth above the original ground surface or an excavation. Final stabilization means all soil disturbing activities at the site have been completed, and that for unpaved areas and areas not covered by permanent structures and areas located outside the waste disposal limits of a landfill cell that has been certified by EPD for waste disposal, 100 percent of the soil surface is uniformly covered in permanent vegetation with a density of 70 percent or greater, or landscaped according to the plan (uniformly covered with landscaping materials in planned landscape areas), or equivalent permanent stabilization measures as defined in the manual (excluding a crop of annual vegetation and seeding of target crop perennials appropriate for the region). Final stabilization applies to each phase of construction. Finished grade means the final elevation and contour of the ground after cutting or filling and conforming to the proposed design. Grading means altering the shape of ground surfaces to a predetermined condition; this includes stripping, cutting, filling, stockpiling and shaping or any combination thereof and shall include the land in its cut or filled condition. Ground elevation means the original elevation of the ground surface prior to cutting or filling. Land disturbing activity means any activity which may result in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediments into state waters or onto lands within the state, including, but not limited to, clearing, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting, and filling of land but not including agricultural practices as described in section 20-21(5). Larger common plan of development or sale means a contiguous area where multiple separate and distinct construction activities are occurring under one plan of development or sale. For the purposes of this paragraph, "plan" means an announcement; piece of documentation such as a sign, public notice or hearing, sales pitch, advertisement, drawing, permit application, zoning request, or computer design; or physical demarcation such as boundary signs, lot stakes, or surveyor markings, indicating that construction activities may occur on a specific plot. Local issuing authority means the governing authority of any county or municipality which is certified pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-7-8(a). Metropolitan River Protection Act (MRPA) means a state law referenced as O.C.G.A. § 12-5-440 et seq. which addresses environmental and developmental matters in certain metropolitan river corridors and their drainage basins. Natural ground surface means the ground surface in its original state before any grading, excavation or filling. Nephelometric turbidity units (NTU) means numerical units of measure based upon photometric analytical techniques for measuring the light scattered by finely divided particles of a substance in suspension. This technique is used to estimate the extent of turbidity in water in which colloidally dispersed or suspended particles are present. NOI means a notice of intent form provided by EPD for coverage under the state general permit. NOT means a notice of termination form provided by EPD to terminate coverage under the state general permit. Operator means the party or parties that have: (A) operational control of construction project plans and specifications, including the ability to make modifications to those plans and specifications; or (B) day-to-day operational control of those activities that are necessary to ensure compliance with an erosion, sedimentation and pollution control plan for the site or other permit conditions, such as a person authorized to direct workers at a site to carry out activities required by the erosion, sedimentation and pollution control plan or to comply with other permit conditions. Outfall means the location where storm water in a discernible, confined and discrete conveyance, leaves a facility or site or, if there is a receiving water on site, becomes a point source discharging into that receiving water. Permit means the authorization necessary to conduct a land disturbing activity under the provisions of this article. Person means any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, state agency, municipality or other political subdivision of the State of Georgia, any interstate body or any other legal entity. Phase or phased means sub-parts or segments of construction projects where the sub-part or segment is constructed and stabilized prior to completing construction activities on the entire construction site. Project means the entire proposed development project regardless of the size of the area of land to be disturbed. Properly designed means designed in accordance with the design requirements and specifications contained in the "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia" (manual) published by the Georgia Soil and Water Conservation Commission as of January 1 of the year in which the land disturbing activity was permitted and amendments to the manual as approved by the commission up until the date of NOI submittal. Roadway drainage structure means a device such as a bridge, culvert, or ditch, composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic, or other such material that conveys water under a roadway by intercepting the flow on one side of a traveled roadway consisting of one or more defined lanes, with or without shoulder areas, and carrying water to a release point on the other side. Sediment means solid material, both organic and inorganic, that is in suspension, is being transported, or has been moved from its site of origin by wind, water, ice, or gravity as a product of erosion. Sedimentation means the process by which eroded material is transported and deposited by the action of water, wind, ice or gravity. Soil and water conservation district approved plan means an erosion, sedimentation and pollution control plan approved in writing by the soil and water conservation district. Stabilization means the process of establishing an enduring soil cover of vegetation by the installation of temporary or permanent structures for the purpose of reducing to a minimum the erosion process and the resultant transport of sediment by wind, water, ice or gravity. State general permit means the National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) general permit or permits for storm water runoff from construction activities as is now in effect or as may be amended or reissued in the future pursuant to the state's authority to implement the same through federal delegation under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. Section 1251, et seq. and O.C.G.A. § 12-5-30(f). State waters means any and all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage systems, springs, wells, and other bodies of surface or subsurface water, natural or artificial, lying within or forming a part of the boundaries of Georgia which are not entirely confined and retained completely upon the property of a single individual, partnership, or corporation. Structural erosion, sedimentation and pollution control practices means practices for the stabilization of erodible or sediment-producing areas by utilizing the mechanical properties of matter for the purpose of either changing the surface of the land or storing, regulating or disposing of runoff to prevent excessive sediment loss. Examples of structural erosion and sediment control practices are riprap, sediment basins, dikes, level spreaders, waterways or outlets, diversions, grade stabilization structures and sediment traps, etc. Such practices can be found in the publication Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia. Trout streams means all streams or portions of streams within the watershed as designated by the wildlife resources division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources under the provisions of the Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20, in the Rules and Regulations for Water Quality Control, Chapter 391-3-6 at www.epd.georgia.gov . Streams designated as primary trout waters are defined as water supporting a self-sustaining population of rainbow, brown or brook trout. Streams designated as secondary trout waters are those in which there is no evidence of natural trout reproduction, but are capable of supporting trout throughout the year. First order trout waters are streams into which no other streams flow except springs. Vegetative erosion and sedimentation control measures means measures for the stabilization of erodible or sediment-producing areas by covering the soil with: (1) Permanent seeding, sprigging or planting, producing long-term vegetative cover; or (2) Temporary seeding, producing short-term vegetative cover; or (3) Sodding, covering areas with a turf of perennial sod-forming grass. Such measures can be found in the publication Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia. Watercourse means any natural or artificial watercourse, stream, river, creek, channel, ditch, canal, conduit, culvert, drain, waterway, gully, ravine, or wash in which water flows either continuously or intermittently and which has a definite channel, bed and banks, and including any area adjacent thereto subject to inundation by reason of overflow or floodwater. Wetlands means those areas that are inundated or saturated by surface or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions. Wetlands generally include swamps, marshes, bogs, and similar areas. (Ord. No. 07-18-02, § II, 8-7-2018) Sec. 20-21. - Exemptions. This article shall apply to any land disturbing activity undertaken by any person on any land except for the following: (1) Surface mining, as the same is defined in O.C.G.A. § 12-4-72, "The Georgia Surface Mining Act of 1968". (2) Granite quarrying and land clearing for such quarrying; (3) Such minor land disturbing activities as home gardens and individual home landscaping, repairs, maintenance work, fences, and other related activities which result in minor soil erosion; (4) The construction of single-family residences, when such construction disturbs less than one acre and is not a part of a larger common plan of development or sale with a planned disturbance of equal to or greater than one acre and not otherwise exempted under this paragraph; provided, however, that construction of any such residence shall conform to the minimum requirements as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6 and this paragraph. For single-family residence construction covered by the provisions of this paragraph, there shall be a buffer zone between the residence and any state waters classified as trout streams pursuant to Article 2 of Chapter 5 of the Georgia Water Quality Control Act. In any such buffer zone, no land disturbing activity shall be constructed between the residence and the point where vegetation has been wrested by normal stream flow or wave action from the banks of the trout waters. For primary trout waters, the buffer zone shall be at least 50 horizontal feet, and no variance to a smaller buffer shall be granted. For secondary trout waters, the buffer zone shall be at least 50 horizontal feet, but the director may grant variances to no less than 25 feet. Regardless of whether a trout stream is primary or secondary, for first order trout waters, which are streams into which no other streams flow except for springs, the buffer shall be at least 25 horizontal feet, and no variance to a smaller buffer shall be granted. The minimum requirements of O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6(b) and the buffer zones provided by this paragraph shall be enforced by the local issuing authority; (5) Agricultural operations as defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3, "definitions", to include raising, harvesting or storing of products of the field or orchard; feeding, breeding or managing livestock or poultry; producing or storing feed for use in the production of livestock, including but not limited to cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits or for use in the production of poultry, including but not limited to chickens, hens and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; the production of aqua culture, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs and apiarian products; farm buildings and farm ponds; (6) Forestry land management practices, including harvesting; provided, however, that when such exempt forestry practices cause or result in land disturbing or other activities otherwise prohibited in a buffer, as established in section 20-22(c)(15), (16) of this article, no other land disturbing activities, except for normal forest management practices, shall be allowed on the entire property upon which the forestry practices were conducted for a period of three years after completion of such forestry practices; (7) Any project carried out under the technical supervision of the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) of the United States Department of Agriculture; (8) Any project involving less than one acre of disturbed area; provided, however, that this exemption shall not apply to any land disturbing activity within a larger common plan of development or sale with a planned disturbance of equal to or greater than one acre or within 200 feet of the bank of any state waters, and for purposes of this paragraph, "state waters" excludes channels and drainage ways which have water in them only during and immediately after rainfall events and intermittent streams which do not have water in them year-round; provided, however, that any person responsible for a project which involves less than one acre, which involves land disturbing activity, and which is within 200 feet of any such excluded channel or drainage way, must prevent sediment from moving beyond the boundaries of the property on which such project is located and provided, further, that nothing contained herein shall prevent the local issuing authority from regulating any such project which is not specifically exempted by paragraphs (1)—(7), (9) or (10) of this section; (9) Construction or maintenance projects, or both, undertaken or financed in whole or in part, or both, by the department of transportation, the Georgia Highway Authority, or the state road and tollway authority; or any road construction or maintenance project, or both, undertaken by any county or municipality; provided, however, that construction or maintenance projects of the department of transportation or the state road and tollway authority which disturb one or more contiguous acres of land shall be subject to provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-7-7.1; except where the department of transportation, the Georgia Highway Authority, or the state road and tollway authority is a secondary permittee for a project located within a larger common plan of development or sale under the state general permit, in which case a copy of a notice of intent under the state general permit shall be submitted to the local issuing authority, the local issuing authority shall enforce compliance with the minimum requirements set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6 as if a permit had been issued, and violations shall be subject to the same penalties as violations by permit holders; (10) Any land disturbing activities conducted by any electric membership corporation or municipal electrical system or any public utility under the regulatory jurisdiction of the public service commission, any utility under the regulatory jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, any cable television system as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-18-1, or any agency or instrumentality of the United States engaged in the generation, transmission, or distribution of power; except where an electric membership corporation or municipal electrical system or any public utility under the regulatory jurisdiction of the public service commission, any utility under the regulatory jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, any cable television system as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-18-1, or any agency or instrumentality of the United states engaged in the generation, transmission, or distribution of power is a secondary permittee for a project located within a larger common plan of development or sale under the state general permit, in which case the local issuing authority shall enforce compliance with the minimum requirements set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6 as if a permit had been issued, and violations shall be subject to the same penalties as violations by permit holders; and (11) Any public water system reservoir. (Ord. No. 07-18-02, § III, 8-7-2018) Sec. 20-22. - Minimum requirements for erosion, sedimentation and pollution control using best management practices. (a) General provisions. Excessive soil erosion and resulting sedimentation can take place during land disturbing activities if requirements of the ordinance and the NPDES general permit are not met. Therefore, plans for those land disturbing activities which are not exempted by this article shall contain provisions for application of soil erosion, sedimentation and pollution control measures and practices. The provisions shall be incorporated into the erosion, sedimentation and pollution control plans. Soil erosion, sedimentation and pollution control measures and practices shall conform to the minimum requirements of section 20-22(b) and (c) of this article. The application of measures and practices shall apply to all features of the site, including street and utility installations, drainage facilities and other temporary and permanent improvements. Measures shall be installed to prevent or control erosion, sedimentation and pollution during all stages of any land disturbing activity in accordance with requirements of this article and the NPDES general permit. (b) Minimum requirements/BMPs. (1) Best management practices as set forth in section 20-22(b) and (c) of this article shall be required for all land disturbing activities. Proper design, installation, and maintenance of best management practices shall constitute a complete defense to any action by the director or to any other allegation of noncompliance with paragraph (2) of this subsection or any substantially similar terms contained in a permit for the discharge of storm water issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-30(f), the "Georgia Water Quality Control Act". As used in this subsection the terms "proper design" and "properly designed" mean designed in accordance with the hydraulic design specifications contained in the "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia" specified in O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6(b). (2) A discharge of storm water runoff from disturbed areas where best management practices have not been properly designed, installed, and maintained shall constitute a separate violation of any land disturbing permit issued by a local issuing authority or of any state general permit issued by the division pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-30(f), the "Georgia Water Quality Control Act", for each day on which such discharge results in the turbidity of receiving waters being increased by more than 25 nephelometric turbidity units for waters supporting warm water fisheries or by more than ten nephelometric turbidity units for waters classified as trout waters. The turbidity of the receiving waters shall be measured in accordance with guidelines to be issued by the director. This paragraph shall not apply to any land disturbance associated with the construction of single family homes which are not part of a larger common plan of development or sale unless the planned disturbance for such construction is equal to or greater than five acres. (3) Failure to properly design, install, or maintain best management practices shall constitute a violation of any land disturbing permit issued by a local issuing authority or of any state general permit issued by the division pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-30(f), the "Georgia Water Quality Control Act", for each day on which such failure occurs. (4) The director may require, in accordance with regulations adopted by the board, reasonable and prudent monitoring of the turbidity level of receiving waters into which discharges from land disturbing activities occur. (5) The LIA may set more stringent buffer requirements than stated in section 20-22(c)(15)—(17), in light of O.C.G.A. § 12-7-6(c).
