The term does not, however, include; (1) those improvements of a structure required to comply with existing violations of state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions and which have been identified by the code enforcement official, and not solely triggered by an improvement or repair project; or (2) any alteration of a "historic structure" provided that the alteration will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a "historic structure". Substantially improved existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions means where the repair, reconstruction, rehabilitation or improvement of the streets, utilities and pads equals or exceeds 50 percent of the value of the streets, utilities and pads before the repair, reconstruction or improvement commenced. Variance means a grant of relief from the requirements of this article, which permits construction in a manner otherwise prohibited by this article. Violation means the failure of a structure or other development to be fully compliant with the community's floodplain management regulations. A structure or other development without the elevation certificate, or other certifications, or other evidence of compliance required by this article is presumed to be in violation until such time as that documentation is provided. (Ord. No. 07-16-01, 8-2-2016) ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— At the direction of the city, art. IV. entitled "Tree preservation", §§ 20-177—20-192, has been removed from the Code of Ordinances. Said article derived from Prior Code, §§ 35-1—35-16.
Secs. 20-177—20-220. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY HEALTH RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 20-221. - Rules and regulations. (a) State promulgated rules and regulations. (1) The following rules and regulations of the Georgia DCH, including all subsequent amendments, revisions or modifications thereto, and which are expressly incorporated herein, are hereby adopted and approved for enforcement as set forth herein: a. Control of Rabies, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-2. See Ch. 8, Animals. b. Food Service, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-14. c. Tourist Accommodations, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-18. d. Land Disposal of Domestic Setage, Comp. R.and Regs. § 290-5-25. e. On-Site Sewage Management Systems, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-26. f. Drinking Water Supply, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-55. g. Solid Waste, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-56. h. Special On-Site Sewage Management Systems, Comp. R. and Regs. § 250-5-59. i. The Georgia Smokefree Air Act of 2005, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-61. j. Swimming Pools and Recreational Water Parks, Comp. R. and Regs. § 290-5-57. (2) Copies of those DCH rules and regulations are on file in the office of the city clerk, where the same are available for inspection and copying by the public during regular city operating hours. (b) Local board of health enactments. (1) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-3-1, et seq., in addition to the above-referenced rules and regulations of the Georgia DCH, the following rules and regulations have been enacted by the Habersham County Board of Health and are hereby adopted by the city in accordance with state law, and are: a. Rules and regulations concerning body art, enacted by resolution dated February 9, 2009, which are hereby set forth verbatim herein and adopted by the city council upon lawful adoption of this article. b. Rules and regulations concerning rabies control, enacted by resolution dated February 9, 2009, which are hereby set forth verbatim herein and adopted by the city council upon lawful adoption of this article. (2) Copies of those rules and regulations enacted by the Habersham County Board of Health, and having been adopted by the city, are on file in the office of the city clerk, where the same are available for inspection and copying by the public during regular city operating hours. (c) In addition, the rules and regulations concerning minimum lot sizes for the orderly and safe development of property utilizing on-site sewage management systems, having been enacted by resolution dated February 9, 2009 by the Habersham County Board of Health, are hereby adopted and made a part of this article as though fully set out at length herein to the extent that same are not in conflict with the existing Code of Ordinances of the City of Cornelia, the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Cornelia and the Subdivision Regulations of the City of Cornelia. The city may require different minimum lot sizes for utilization of on-site sewage management systems in zoning or land use districts providing for septic service, and in the event there is a conflict between the lot size(s) established by the Habersham County Board of Health and that established by the city, the lot size(s) established by the city shall control and take precedence. (d) A fee schedule for the implementation and confirmation of compliance with the above-referenced DCH rules and regulations and local board of health enactments, including permit and inspection fees, has been established by the Habersham County Board of Health, and is hereby adopted by the city. A copy of this fee schedule, including all subsequent amendments, revisions or modifications thereto, is on file in the office of the city clerk and is available for inspection and copying by the public during regular city operating hours. (e) The enforcement and prosecution of this article shall be within the jurisdiction of the City of Cornelia and the Habersham County Board of Health, and their authorized designee(s) or agent(s), and all law enforcement personnel of the City of Cornelia, Georgia. (f) It shall be unlawful for any natural person or persons or any legal entity including, and not limited to, a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, firm or trust, to violate any of the above-identified rules and regulations, and/or to fail or refuse to pay any fee established by the Habersham County Board of Health, and adopted by the city, for the implementation and confirmation of compliance with the above-identified rules and regulations, including all permit and inspection fees. (g) Any person or persons or any legal entity including, and not limited to, a corporation, partnership, limited liability company, firm or trust, violating any provision of the rules and regulations identified and adopted in this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or six months imprisonment, or both; provided however, that for any single violation the period of imprisonment shall not exceed 120 days; and provided, further, that the judge may probate any part or all of any punishment imposed pursuant to this section, as allowed pursuant to section 1-12 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cornelia. (h) Each day during which a violation of any provision of the rules and regulations identified and adopted in this article shall constitute, and shall be considered, a separate offense. (i) The Municipal Court of Cornelia, Georgia shall have original jurisdiction upon any offense charged pursuant to this article. (j) In addition to the rights and remedies set forth herein, or as otherwise authorized by law, the city, and the Habersham County Board of Health, retain and reserve the right to seek equitable relief, injunction, abatement, or any appropriate action or proceeding to protect the public health, safety and welfare. Failure or refusal to pay any fee approved for the implementation and confirmation of compliance with the above-identified rules and regulations, including all permit and inspection fees, may result in suspension and/or revocation of any permit issued by the Habersham County Board of Health. (k) Violations of all DCH promulgated rules and regulations and all local board of health enactments identified herein may be prosecuted by an accusation or citation, with or without a prosecuting attorney; and the city hereby authorizes the city attorney or his designee to prosecute violations of this article. (l) This article, and the enforcement and prosecution of this article by the city and the Habersham County Board of Health, and their authorized agent(s) or designee(s), does not in any way effect, stop, prescribe, regulate, limit, or in any way control or prohibit the Georgia DCH, and its agent(s) or designee(s), from initiating or undertaking any action or proceeding to enforce compliance with its rules and regulations. (m) This article shall become effective immediately upon its adoption by the City Commission of the City of Cornelia, Georgia. Any and all existing or pre-existing ordinances and provisions in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 06-10-01, §§ I—XIII, 7-13-2010) Secs. 20-222—20-245. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 22 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Power of municipality to levy and collect taxes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I; ad valorem tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - City tax digest; billing for ad valorem taxes; due date. Upon receipt of a copy of the county tax digest for each year, the city tax digest for such year shall be prepared without delay, and bills for ad valorem taxes for such year shall be mailed to the taxpayers as soon thereafter as they can be calculated and prepared for mailing. All ad valorem taxes shall become due and payable 60 days after the date of mailing of the bills therefor. On the 61st day after the mailing of the tax bills, the books for the collection of taxes shall be closed, and on the following day, tax executions for all unpaid taxes shall issue. (Prior Code, § 10-1) State Law reference— County and municipality may contract for county tax commissioner to prepare tax digest for municipality, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359.1. Sec. 22-2. - Correction of assessments. If, at any time after the permanent tax digest is prepared for any year, corrections are made by the appropriate officials of the county in any of the valuations of property assessed for taxes by the city and appearing on the county tax digest, the secretary of the city commission shall make such corrections on the permanent tax digest of the city and prepare a corrected billing for the taxpayers involved, calculated on the basis of such corrected valuations. (Prior Code, § 10-3) Sec. 22-3. - Collection costs for delinquent ad valorem taxes. Customers that have a past-due balance after the due date for their ad valorem taxes are subject to being referred to collection agencies and are required to pay for postage, second notices, collection fees, court processing fees and attorney fees. (Ord. No. 06-09-03, 7-7-2009) Secs. 22-4—22-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MOTEL EXCISE TAX[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Excise tax on rooms, lodging and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; imposition, rate, collection, and assessment, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-30 et seq.; local governments, limitation on imposition and calculation of regulatory fees, construction with other laws, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b)(23).
Sec. 22-23. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Due date means the 20th day after the end of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. Guestroom means a room occupied or intended, arranged or designed for occupancy by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. Monthly period means a calendar month. Motel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any motel, lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, hotel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, bed and breakfast inn, public club, or private club, containing guestrooms and which is occupied or is intended or designed for occupancy by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. Such term does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention center, or other building in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. Occupancy means the use or possession or the right to the use or possession of any room or apartment in a motel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. Occupant or guest means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a motel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. Operator means any person operating a motel in the city, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, the lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee, or any other person otherwise operating such motel. Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind in nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Return means any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. Secretary means the secretary of the city commission. Tax means the tax imposed by this chapter. (Prior Code, § 32-1) Sec. 22-24. - Imposition and rate of tax. (a) There is hereby levied and imposed and shall be paid a tax of eight percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guestroom in a motel in the city; provided that the levy and collection of that portion of such tax amounting to three percent of the rent which is required to be expended for the purpose of promoting tourism, conventions, and trade shows, or for other purposes provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3), shall be suspended during periods of time during which the city has no contract for the expenditure of such funds with the state, a department of the state government, a state authority, or a private sector nonprofit organization, or a contract with some combination of such entities. Written notice of the dates of the beginning and end of such a period of suspension shall be given by the secretary of the city commission or his/her designee to each operator of a motel in the city on or before the date immediately preceding the date each period begins and ends. Such notice shall be deemed sufficient if delivered to any person authorized to collect rent for the operator of the motel to whom notice is required to be given. (b) Such tax shall be paid upon any occupancy, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease or other arrangement. Where rent is paid, charged or billed, or falls due on either a weekly, monthly or other term basis, the rent so paid, charged, billed or falling due shall be subject to the tax imposed by this section to the extent that it covers any portion of any monthly period. (c) No tax shall be levied as provided in this section upon the fees or charges for any room, lodging or accommodation furnished for a period of more than ten consecutive days or for use as a meeting room. (Prior Code, § 32-2; Res. No. 12-09-01, § I, 12-1-2009; Ord. No. 06-17-02, 6-20-2017) Sec. 22-25. - Collection of tax by operator. It shall be the duty of every operator of a motel located within the city to collect from the occupants the tax levied and imposed upon the occupancy of guestrooms by the provisions of this article. (Prior Code, § 32-3) Sec. 22-26. - Exemptions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no tax shall be levied as provided in this article upon the fee or charge for any room, lodging or accommodation furnished for use by any state or local government official or employee, when traveling on official business. (Prior Code, § 32-4) Sec. 22-27. - Registration of operator. (a) Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a motel in the city shall immediately register with the secretary of the city commission on a form provided by the secretary. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his/her place of business, and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the secretary may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner, if a natural person, by a member or partner, if owned by an association or partnership, or by an executive officer, if owned by a corporation. (b) A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. (c) Should the secretary of the city commission deem it necessary in order to facilitate registration, he/she may prescribe administrative provisions therefor other than those provided in this section. Such provisions shall be made to effect the purposes hereof. (Prior Code, § 32-5) Sec. 22-28. - Certificate of taxing authority. Upon the registration of an operator as provided in section 22-27, the secretary of the city commission shall issue to such operator, without charge, a certificate of authority to collect the tax from the occupants, stating the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. Such certificates shall be nonassignable and nontransferable and shall be returned immediately to the secretary upon the cessation of business by the registered operator at the location named or upon the sale or transfer of such business at such location. (Prior Code, § 32-6) Sec. 22-29. - Due date of taxes. All taxes levied and imposed by this article shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period in which such taxes are collected. (Prior Code, § 32-7) Sec. 22-30. - Returns and time of filing; remittance of tax. (a) On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the secretary of the city commission, in such form as the secretary may prescribe, by every operator liable for the payment of the tax hereunder. (b) All returns shall show the gross rent, exempt rent, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the monthly period for which filed, and such other information as may be required by the secretary and shall be accompanied, when filed, by remittance of the net amount of tax due. (Prior Code, § 32-8) Sec. 22-31. - Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax levied under this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and payment of the amount due, provided such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50, as now or hereafter amended. (Prior Code, § 32-9) Sec. 22-32. - Deficiency determinations. (a) Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the secretary of the city commission is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person, he/she may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information in his/her possession or which may come into his/her possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. (b) Interest on deficiency. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of 0.75 percent per month from and after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax and interest. (c) Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the secretary may offset overpayments for a period against an unpaid tax found to be due for another period against penalties, and against the interest on such unpaid tax. (d) Notice of determination; service. The secretary or his/her designee shall give to the operator written notice of his/her determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his/her address as it appears in the records of the secretary. (e) Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall expire later. (Prior Code, § 32-10) Sec. 22-33. - Determination without return. (a) Estimation of gross receipts. If any operator fails to make a return, the secretary of the city commission shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the operator or, as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period for which the operator failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the secretary. Upon the basis of this estimate, the secretary shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made of the amount due for one or for more monthly periods. (b) Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the secretary may offset overpayments for a period against an unpaid tax found to be due for another period against penalties and against interest on an unpaid tax found to be due. The interest on such unpaid tax shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection 22-32(b). (c) Interest on amount found due. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of 0.75 percent per month from and after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax, penalties and interest. (d) Notice of determination; service . Promptly after making his/her determination, the secretary shall give to the operator written notice of his/her determination, which may be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. (Prior Code, § 32-11) Sec. 22-34. - Collection of tax. (a) Action for tax; time for. When it is determined by a return filed or by the secretary having made a determination under the provisions of sections 22-32 or 22-33 that tax is due and payable to the city under the provisions of this article, the city manager may, at any time within three years after determination that such tax is due and payable, bring an action in the court of the state, any other state, or of the United States in the name of the city to collect the amount of tax payable to the city, together with interest thereon and penalties, court costs, attorney's fees and other legal fees incidental thereto. The bringing of such an action shall not be a prerequisite for the issuance of a fieri facias under the provisions of subsection (d) of this section. (b) Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount of tax under this article sells or transfers his/her business, his/her successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price of the business to cover such amount of tax, interest thereon, and penalties, and pay such sum to the city unless the operator liable for such tax delivers to such purchaser or transferee, as the case may be, at the time of such sale or transfer, a certificate from the secretary showing that all tax returns required of such operator have been filed and all taxes shown as being payable on such returns have been paid in full. (c) Liability for failure to withhold; time to enforce successors's liability. If the purchaser or transferee of a business fails to withhold the required amount of the purchase price, he/she shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him/her to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells or transfers his/her business, or at such time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event occurs later. (d) Issuance of fieri facias. The secretary is hereby authorized to issue a fieri facias for execution and levy to satisfy the amount of any tax, penalty or interest due but not paid under the provisions of this article. (Prior Code, § 32-12) Sec. 22-35. - Administration. (a) Authority of secretary. The secretary of the city commission, under supervision of the city manager, shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. (b) Rules and regulations. The secretary shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or ordinances of the city, the laws of the state, or the Constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes hereunder. (c) Records. Every operator shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the secretary of the city commission may require. (d) Examination of records; audits. The secretary or any person authorized in writing by him/her may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount of tax required to be paid. (e) Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the secretary may require the filing of reports by any person having in his/her/its possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax under this article. The reports shall be filed with the secretary when required by the secretary and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the dates of occupancy, and such other information as the secretary may require. (f) Limitation on disclosure of business of operators, etc. The secretary or any person having an administrative duty under this article shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations, or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures or any particular thereof set forth or disclosed in any return, or permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this article, except in case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax hereby levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax, interest and penalties required to be collected. (Prior Code, § 32-13) Sec. 22-36. - Agents for receiving notices. When registering pursuant to section 22-27, each operator shall appoint, in writing, an agent to receive for the operator any notice to be given to the operator under the provisions of this article, stating the full name, street address, mailing address and telephone number of such agent. Such agent shall be either an individual resident of the city or an employee of the operator who regularly works at the operator's place of business on a daily basis, and the appointment of the agent must be accompanied by the written consent of such appointed person to serve as agent for the operator. Such agent may be changed from time to time by written appointment of and consent of a successor agent. The operator is required to have such an agent at all times, and should an agent cease to be a resident of the city or an employee regularly working at the operator's place of business in the city, as the case may be, the operator shall immediately file a written appointment of a new agent and such agent's consent to serve as such with the secretary. Any agent so appointed by an operator shall be authorized to receive for and on behalf of the operator any notice required to be given to the operator by the provisions of this article. Delivery of any such notice to such agent, in person or by mail, shall be sufficient to meet the requirements of this article, and such notice shall be binding on the operator. This method of giving notice to operators is supplementary and cumulative of the other methods of giving notice set forth in this article. (Prior Code, § 32-14) Sec. 22-37. - Violations; fines and punishment. A violation of this article shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 32-15) Secs. 22-38—22-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS
Sec. 22-51. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Frontage means that side or limit of the lot or parcel of land in question which abuts on the improvement or on a street within which the improvement is located or installed either above or below ground level. Improve and improvement mean and include the grading, regrading, paving, repaving, macadamizing and remacadamizing of streets, sidewalks or other public places or ways; the construction, reconstruction, relocating and altering of curbing, guttering, storm sewers, catchbasins, sidewalks, street lights, devices to control the flow of traffic on streets and roads, sewer lines, taps and connections to sewer lines, lift stations for lines, water lines, taps and connections for water lines, all appurtenances or other connections therein; and the cost of administration. Pave means and includes storm draining, catchbasins, curbs, gutters, paving, macadamizing, clearing and grading. Sewer or sewer line means and includes sewer mains, lift stations and sewer taps and connections. Street means and includes streets, roads, highways, avenues, alleys, sidewalks and other public places or ways. Water or water line means and includes water mains, taps and connections. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 1, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-52. - Resolution for improvements; publication required; protest; petition for improvements. (a) Whenever the city commission shall deem it necessary to construct, build or improve any street, road or highway or any part thereof, including storm drains, curbs, gutters, catchbasins, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic on streets and roads within the unincorporated area of the county or to acquire, construct, build or improve any sewer or water line within the unincorporated area of the county, the city commission shall by resolution declare such improvement necessary to be done, and publish the resolution once in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements of the county are published. If the owners of a majority of the tracts of land abutting on the improvement shall not, within ten days after the date of the publication of the resolution, file with the city commission their protest in writing against such improvement and set forth therein their names and addresses, the city commission shall have the authority to cause the improvements to be made, to contract therefor and to make assessments and fix liens as provided for in section 22-62. Any number of streets, roads or highways or any part thereof, or any number of water or sewer lines or any part thereof, to be so improved may be included in one resolution; but any protest or objection shall be made as to each street, road or highway or any part thereof separately and as to any section of water or sewer line separately. (b) If, however, the owners of a majority of the parcels of land liable to assessment for such improvement shall petition the city commission for such improvement and designate in the petition by general description the improvements to be undertaken and the streets, roads, highways or any part thereof, sewer lines or water lines to be improved, constructed or installed, it shall thereupon be the duty of the city commission to proceed, as provided in section 22-55, to cause the improvement to be made in accordance with the prayers of the petition if deemed feasible and desirable by the city commission in the exercise of its discretion. In such cases the resolution mentioned in this section shall not be required. The petition or petitions shall be filed with the county clerk who shall investigate the sufficiency thereof, submit the petition to the city commission, and certify the result of his investigation. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 2, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-53. - Method of assessment for costs. (a) Each lot or parcel of land abutting upon the improvement or along which the water line or sewer line is to be installed shall be charged on a basis of lineal-foot frontage at an equal rate per foot of such frontage with its just pro rata of the entire cost of the improvement, water line or sewer line. (b) The cost of sidewalks, curbs and gutters shall be charged entirely to the lots or parcels of land abutting on that side of the street upon which the sidewalks, curbs and gutters are to be constructed. (c) In the case of a water or sewer line being constructed or installed within the right-of-way of a road, street or highway irrespective of the actual location of the water or sewer line within the road, street or highway, the lots or parcels fronting on both sides of the street, road or highway shall be charged with its just pro rata cost. (d) The frontage of intersecting streets shall be assessed as real estate abutting upon the improvement, and the county shall be deemed as the owner thereof. The chairman of the city commission shall have authority to sign the petition or file objections provided for in section 22-52(a). (e) The city commission shall pay its just pro rata of the entire cost of the improvements, unless the owners of a majority of the parcels of land shall agree to pay the entire cost of the improvement, or unless in the resolution provided for in this section, it shall be stated that the entire cost of the improvement is to be paid by the abutting property owners or that a percent of the cost would be paid for by the city. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 3, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-54. - Costs included in assessment. Whenever a petition signed by the owners of a majority of the parcels of land liable for assessment is presented to the city commission, or when the city commission shall have determined by resolution to build, construct or improve any street, road, highway, sidewalk, street light or device to control the flow of traffic on streets and roads or build and construct a water line or sewer line, the city commission shall enact all ordinances and establish all rules and regulations as may be necessary to require the owners of all the property abutting on the improvement to pay the cost of the improvement; to cause to be put in and constructed all water or sewer pipe connections to connect with any existing water or sewer pipes in and underneath the streets where such improvements are to be made; and all cost and expenses of making such connections shall be included and made a part of the general assessment to cover the cost of such improvement. Where a water line is to be installed, the cost of fire hydrants and line connections and pipe to the edge of a street, road or highway shall be made a cost of the general assessment; and where a sewer line is to be installed, the cost of sewer taps or connections shall be made a cost of the general assessment to cover the cost of such improvement. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 4, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-55. - Resolution on manner of improvement. After the expiration of the time for objection or protest on the part of the property owners, if no sufficient protest is filed by a majority of the property owners, or upon receipt of a petition requesting the improvements signed by the owners of a majority of the parcels of land to be assessed, if such petition is found to be in proper form and properly executed, the city commission shall adopt a resolution reciting that a protest has not been filed by a majority of the property owners and expressing the determination of the city commission to proceed with the improvement, setting forth the nature of the improvements and defining the extent and character of the improvements, and such other matters as may be necessary to instruct the city engineer or other engineers employed by the city to prepare the necessary plans, plats, profiles, specifications and estimates. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 5, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-56. - Public hearing on proposed improvement. (a) Where a petition was not filed with the city commission by a majority of the property owners and within ten days from the date of publication of the resolution protests are filed by a majority of the property owners, the city commission shall set a date for a public hearing to consider the protests. (b) Notification of the date of the hearing shall be given to all objectors by certified mail where both the names and addresses of the objectors appear in the petition. (c) The city commission shall, at the public hearing and in the exercise of their discretion, have the right to abandon the project or proceed with the improvement and define the extent and character of the improvement and such other matters as may be necessary to instruct the city engineer or other engineers engaged or employed by the city to prepare the necessary plans, plats, profiles, specifications and cost estimates. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 6, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-57. - Estimate of assessment. Where the project has been authorized by resolution of the city commission, the city manager and project engineer shall file with the city commission a written report of the appraisal, assessment, cost estimates and the cost upon the several lots or tracts of land to be assessed as well as an estimate of that portion of the cost, if any, to be paid for by the city. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 7, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-58. - Public hearing on estimate of assessment. (a) When the report is returned and filed, the city commission shall set a time and place for the holding of a public hearing of any complaint or objections that may be made concerning the appraisement, apportionment and assessment by any person interested. Notice of the hearing shall be published by the city clerk one time ten days prior to the date of the hearing in the county paper where the sheriff's advertisements are published. The notice shall provide for an inspection of the return by any property owner or other party interested in the return. (b) The city commission at the session shall have power, and it shall be its duty, to review and correct the appraisement, apportionment and assessment; to hear objections to the same; and to confirm the same, either as made by the finance director and project engineer or as corrected and amended by the city commission. (c) The city commission shall by ordinances fix the amount the city shall contribute toward the improvement and fix the assessments against the parcels of land in accordance with the approved appraisement cost estimate and apportionment, as so confirmed against the several parcels of land liable therefor. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 8, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-59. - Payment of assessment. Assessments in conformity to the appraisement, cost estimate and apportionment, as confirmed by the city commission, shall be payable to the city manager or a designee thereof in cash, and, if paid within 30 days from the date of passage of the ordinance, shall be without interest. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 9, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-60. - Installments; interest. The city commission may provide for payment of the assessment in equal annual installments. The installments shall bear interest at the rate of not exceeding nine percent per annum until paid. Each installment, together with the interest on the entire amount remaining unpaid, shall be payable each year at such time and place as shall be provided by resolution of the city commission. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 10, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-61. - Additional assessment for shortages. If any special assessment shall be found to be invalid or insufficient in whole or in part for any reason whatsoever, the city commission may at any time, in the manner provided for the making of an original assessment, proceed to cause a new assessment to be made and fixed, which shall have like force and effect as an original assessment. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 11, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-62. - Collection; liens. Each special assessment and each installment thereof, the interest thereon and the expense of collection are hereby declared to be a lien against the lots and tracts of land so assessed from the date of the ordinance levying the lien, coequal with the lien of other taxes and prior to and superior to all other liens against such lots or tracts. Such lien shall continue until such assessment and interest thereon shall be fully paid, and shall be enforced in the same manner as are state, county, and city ad valorem property taxes by issuance of a writ of fieri facias (fi.fa.) and levy and sale as set forth in O.C.G.A. 48-5-121 et seq., which procedure is by reference incorporated in this section and made a part of this article. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 12, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-63. - Assessment dockets. Assessment dockets shall be prepared which shall identify each parcel assessed, the street or road on which each parcel abuts, the owner of the property at the time the assessment was made, the date of the assessment, the improvement for which the assessment was made, the amount of the assessment and the rate of interest and annual payment schedule. The assessment docket for assessments for water or sewer improvements shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk in city hall of the City of Cornelia, or at a location which the city manager may deem appropriate so that the dockets may be available for inspection by the public. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 13, 5-2-2017) Sec. 22-64. - Annual rate for street light assessments based on actual costs. The annual rate for street light assessments shall be based on the actual cost of the installation, operation and maintenance of the category of street light. Street light rates shall be classified into eight categories: UR-Residential Underground, RR-Residential Overhead, Commercial 1, Commercial 2, Commercial 3, Commercial 4, Commercial 5, and Commercial 6. Rates for each of these categories for the current year shall be based on the actual cost to operate and maintain the street lights within the same category in the prior year. (Ord. No. 04-17-01, § 14, 5-2-2017)

div.head: Chapter 24 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
div.p: Sec. 24-1. - Adoption by reference. There is hereby adopted by reference the International Fire Code in its most current edition pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20. (Prior Code, § 11-1) Sec. 24-2. - Enforcement. The International Fire Prevention Code adopted by reference in section 24-1 shall be enforced by the chief of the fire department. (Prior Code, § 11-2) Sec. 24-3. - Fire inspections. The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. Such an inspector shall have the title "fire inspector" and the authority to perform all acts and duties of the fire official set forth in the International Fire Prevention Code adopted by reference in section 24-1. (Prior Code, § 11-3) Sec. 24-4. - Fire code definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in the International Fire Prevention Code adopted by reference in section 24-1, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: Applicable governing body means the city commission. Board of adjustments and appeals means the board of adjustments established under the provisions of appendix B to this Code, the city zoning ordinance. Fire prevention department means the fire department of the city. Fire official means the chief of the fire department. (Prior Code, § 11-4) Sec. 24-5. - Penalties and punishment. A violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 11-8) Sec. 24-6. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Residence means any house, dwelling, mobile home, or structure of any kind used for residential purposes. Year's service means fire protection service during a year, beginning on August 1 and ending on July 31 of the following year, notwithstanding the fact that fire protection service may be subscribed for during such year and that the subscriber may, therefore, receive less than a full 12 months' service. The term "year's service" does not mean fire protection service for a calendar year. (Prior Code, § 11-9) Sec. 24-7. - Charges. The charges for fire protection service furnished to other municipalities and persons owning property in unincorporated areas shall be in sums established by the city commission. (Prior Code, § 11-10) Sec. 24-8. - Charges for residences on city water system. All residences located without the corporate limits of the city but served by water lines of the city shall be furnished fire protection, and the occupant of each such residence shall be charged on a monthly basis for such service. Such charge shall be payable in advance and shall be added to the monthly water bill for water furnished to each such residence; provided that the owner of any such residence may decline fire protection by written notice to the city, delivered to the secretary of the city commission at his/her office in the city hall by such owner, whereupon the occupant of such residence shall be relieved of the aforesaid charge for fire protection and fire protection will not be furnished to such residence by the city. (Prior Code, § 11-11) Sec. 24-9. - Registration and payment of charges for residences. (a) Persons owning residences which are located in unincorporated areas and which are not served by water lines of the city or by lines of a municipality which has contracted with the city for fire protection under the terms of this chapter may obtain fire protection for such residences by registering with the city fire department and paying in advance the required charges as established by the city commission for the month in which such owner registers and for the succeeding period of time ending with the next July 31. Thereafter, the charges for each succeeding year's service shall be due and paid in advance on or before July 31 immediately prior to the commencement of the succeeding year of service. (b) In registering for such service, the owner shall provide the city fire department with his/her name, address, telephone number, a description of the residence for which the service is subscribed, the location of such residence, the most direct route by which such residence may be reached with fire fighting equipment, the nearest source of water available for fighting fire at such residence, the name of the insurance carrier providing insurance coverage for such residence, and the name, address and telephone number of the local agent of such insurance carrier. (c) With the exception of residences served by water lines of the city or by water lines of a municipality which has contracted with the city for fire protection under the terms of this chapter, no residence located in an unincorporated area will be furnished fire protection unless the owner of the same has first complied with the provisions of this chapter. (Prior Code, § 11-12) Sec. 24-10. - Registration and payment of charges for buildings other than residences. (a) Persons owning business, commercial, industrial, professional, and agricultural buildings and any other buildings other than residences which are located in unincorporated areas and which are not served by the water lines of a municipality which has contracted with the city for fire protection under the terms of this chapter may obtain fire protection for such buildings by registering with the city fire department and paying in advance the required charges for the month in which such owner registers and for the succeeding period of time ending with the next July 31. Thereafter, the charges for each succeeding year's service shall be due and paid in advance on or before July 31 immediately prior to the commencement of the succeeding year of service. (b) In registering for such service, the owner shall provide the city fire department with his/her name, address, telephone number, a description of the building for which the service is subscribed, including the amount of floor space, the location of the building, the most direct route by which such building may be reached with fire fighting equipment, the nearest source of water available for fighting fire at such building, the name of the insurance carrier providing insurance coverage for such building, and the name, address, and telephone number of the local agent of such insurance carrier. (c) No business, industrial, commercial, professional, or agricultural building, or any other building located in an unincorporated area and which is not served by the water lines of a municipality which has contracted with the city for fire protection will be furnished fire protection unless the owner of the same has complied with the provisions of this section. (d) Owners of business, commercial, industrial, professional, and agricultural buildings and all other buildings other than residences which are located in unincorporated areas and which are served by water lines of a municipality which has contracted with the city for fire protection under the terms of this chapter shall also register with the fire department and provide the fire department with the owner's name, address, telephone number, a description of the building to be served, including the amount of floor space, the location of the building, the most direct route by which such building may be reached with fire fighting equipment, the nearest source of water available for fighting fire at such building, the name of the insurance carrier providing insurance coverage for such building, and the name, address, and telephone number of the local agent of such insurance carrier. (e) No business, commercial, industrial, professional, or agricultural building or any other building located in an unincorporated area and which is served by water lines of a municipality which has contracted with the city for fire protection will be furnished fire protection unless the owner of the same has first registered with the city fire department as provided in this section. (Prior Code, § 11-13) Sec. 24-11. - Authority to enter into agreements with other municipalities. (a) The city manager is authorized to enter into agreements on behalf of the city with the City of Demorest, the Town of Mt. Airy, the City of Baldwin, and the Town of Alto for the purpose of furnishing fire protection to such municipalities, with each municipality contracting with the city for fire protection to be charged for such service as follows: (1) A charge per month for each water customer on its municipal water system within its corporate limits; (2) A charge per month for each residence located without its corporate limits but served by its water lines; and (3) The monthly charges set forth by the city commission for all business, commercial, industrial, professional, and agricultural buildings and all other buildings located without its corporate limits but served by its water lines, the owners of which have registered with the city as required by the provisions of section 24-10. (b) The charges established in subsection (a) of this section shall be due and payable on or before the tenth of the month following the month for which such sums are owed. (1) The number of water customers within the corporate limits referred to in subsection (a)(1) of this section for which a contracting municipality shall be charged shall be equal to the number of water customers within the corporate limits of such municipality charged by such municipality for water for the month for which the charges specified in (a)(1) of this section are owed. (2) The number of residences without the corporate limits referred to in subsection (a)(2) of this section for which such municipality shall be charged shall be equal to the number of residences without its corporate limits, the occupants of which are charged by such municipality for water for the month for which the charges specified in (a)(2) of this section are owed. (3) Each monthly payment by a contracting municipality for the charges provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be accompanied by a statement of the number of water customers within its corporate limits referred to in subsection (a)(1) of this section, the number of residences without its corporate limits referred to in subsection (a)(2) of this section, and the number of buildings described in subsection (a)(3) of this section upon which such payment is calculated. (4) All records of a contracting municipality pertaining to its sales of water shall be open for examination by any accountant employed by the city or any other person designated by the city manager at any time during the usual business hours of the office of the clerk of such municipality. (c) Government institutions, private institutions and private businesses located within the corporate limits of the municipalities cited in subsection (a) of this section may contract with the city for fire protection at the monthly charges set forth by the city commission after providing written evidence to the city manager that the municipality in which such institution or business is located poses no objection to such contract. In any such case, the registration requirements set forth in section 24-10 shall apply. (d) The owner of any residence or any business, commercial, industrial, professional, or agricultural building or other building located without the corporate limits of a municipality contracting with the city for fire protection who is charged as provided in this section may decline fire protection by written notice to the city, delivered to the secretary of the city commission at his/her office in the city hall by such owner, whereupon the contracting municipality shall be relieved of the charge for fire protection of such residence or building and fire protection will not be furnished to such residence or building by the city. (Prior Code, § 11-14) Sec. 24-12. - Outside burning for land clearing, construction, or right-of-way maintenance. (a) Outside burning for purposes of land clearing, construction or right-of-way maintenance shall be subject to the following: (1) All such burning shall require the approval of the EPD, and the city fire department. (2) Prevailing winds at the time of the burning must be away from the major portion of the city's population. (3) The location of the burning must be at least 1,000 feet from any occupied structure. (4) Burning may occur less than 1,000 feet but at least 300 feet from any occupied structure if an air curtain destructor is used. (5) No more than one air curtain destructor may be operated within a ten acre area at one time. (6) The amount of dirt on or in the material being burned must be minimized. (7) Heavy oils, asphalt materials, items containing natural or synthetic rubber, or any materials other than plant growth may not be burned. (8) No more than one pile, 60 feet by 60 feet or equivalent, may be burned within a nine-acre area at one time. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to build or make fires within the city limits except as follows: (1) Outdoor fires may be used for cooking and/or warmth. (2) All outdoor fires must be contained in an approved fire pit. (3) Outdoor fires are only to be built with the permission and under the supervision of the property owner or occupant. (4) There must be an adequate water supply immediately available. (5) The burning of brush, leaves, trash, or any materials other than firewood is prohibited. (Prior Code, § 11-15; Ord. No. 05-07-01, § 2, 6-5-2007; Ord. No. 12-17-02, § 1, 1-9-2018) Sec. 24-13. - Unlawful to give false information of fire. It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false information or make any false statement to the fire chief or any member of the fire department, to the secretary of the city commission, or to any official, officer, agent or employee of the city with reference to any fire. (Prior Code, § 11-16) Sec. 24-14. - Life Safety Code—Adopted by reference. There is hereby adopted by the city and made a part of this Code by reference the Life Safety Code in its most current edition. (Prior Code, § 11-18) Sec. 24-15. - Same—Authority having jurisdiction. For the purpose of the Life Safety Code adopted by reference in section 24-14, the "authority having jurisdiction" shall be the chief of the fire department. (Prior Code, § 11-20) Sec. 24-16. - Automatic fire sprinkler system required. (a) New construction and remodeling or repair projects exceeding 50 percent of the replacement value of the structure shall be equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler system installed in assembly, educational, healthcare, mercantile, residential, business, industrial and storage structures, with the following exceptions: (1) Detached structure of less than 10,000 square feet; (2) Structures built on single-family lots (i.e., single-family house, garage or shed); and (3) Detached one-story unenclosed covered storage areas. (b) The installation of the automatic fire sprinkler system required under subsection (a) of this section shall not commence until the city planner has issued a permit for such work. Such permit may be issued as part of the building permit for new structures. In cases of uncertainty regarding whether a proposed building or structure conforms to any provisions within these regulations, the city planner shall make the determination. (Prior Code, § 11-21; Ord. No. 02-06-01, § 1, 3-7-2006) Sec. 24-17. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-15-01, adopted Aug. 4, 2015, deleted § 24-17 entitled "Outside burning of yard debris", which derived from Ord. No. 05-07-01, § 1, adopted June 5, 2007. Sec. 24-18. - Controlled burning of structures by fire department. Controlled burning of structures by the fire department shall be subject to the following: (1) The only purposes for conducting a controlled burn shall be for firefighter training or the health, safety, or welfare of the public. (2) The property owner of a private structural burn shall provide information requested by the fire chief, including signed permission and a copy of the deed. (3) The property owner shall assume all responsibility for the effects of the burn to adjacent property owners. (4) The fire chief shall obtain EPD approval prior to the burn. (5) Residents and businesses within 500 feet of the controlled burn shall be notified by personal contact, telephone, or written notice posted on their doors 48 hours prior to the planned burn. Such notices shall include the location of the burn and a telephone number to call for information. (Ord. No. 05-07-01, § 3, 6-5-2007) Sec. 24-19. - Lock boxes. (a) Lock box required for new commercial buildings. All new commercial buildings shall have installed a lock box, of a UL type and size approved by the city fire marshal, in a location specified by the city fire marshal prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. (b) Lock box required for existing commercial buildings. All existing commercial buildings equipped with automatic fire detection and/or suppression systems shall have installed a lock box, of UL type and size approved by the city fire marshal, in a location specified by the city fire marshal within six months of the effective date of this ordinance [from which this section is derived]. (c) Lock box required for multifamily residential structures. All multi-family residential structures that have restricted access through locked doors and have a common corridor for access to the living units shall have installed a lock box, of a UL type and size approved by the city fire marshal, in a location specified by the city fire marshal within six months of the effective date of this ordinance. (d) Lock box contents . All lock boxes shall contain labeled keys, easily identified in the field to provide access into the property and/or building, and to any locked areas within the said building as the city fire marshal may direct. (e) Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] Lock box. A secure rapid entry system that is designed to be used by emergency personnel in the event of an emergency to gain entry into a structure by using the enclosed owner provided key(s). This box is usually mounted on the exterior of the building in a location that is specified by the local fire marshal. All boxes shall be UL (Underwriters Laboratories) certified and approved by the city fire marshal. (Ord. No. 03-18-01, 5-1-2018)

div.head: Chapter 26 - HISTORIC BUILDINGS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Adoption of technical codes authorized under home rule powers, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ 3(a)(12); minimum standard technical codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - BUILDING REHABILITATION AND PRESERVATION
Sec. 26-1. - Purpose. (a) It is the purpose of this chapter to encourage the sensitive rehabilitation, restoration, stabilization or preservation of existing buildings throughout the city and to encourage the preservation of buildings and structures deemed to be historic in total or in part; provided, however, that such rehabilitation and preservation efforts should provide for the upgrading of the safety features of any such building or structure to provide a practical level of safety to the public and surrounding property. It is the further purpose of this chapter to provide guidance regarding acceptable alternative solutions and to stimulate enforcement authorities to utilize alternative compliance concepts, wherever practical, to permit the continued use of existing buildings and structures without overly restrictive financial burdens on owners or occupants. (b) The provisions of this chapter shall not be applicable to new construction, except as specifically provided herein. (Prior Code, § 30-1) Sec. 26-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Board of adjustments and appeals means the housing board of adjustments and appeals established under the provisions of this Code. Building system means any utility, mechanical, electrical, structural, egress or fire protection/safety system. Existing building or structure means any completed building or structure which has been placed in service for a minimum of five years. Historic building means any building so designated by the state historic preservation officer as individually significant or as contributing to the historic character of a historic district, pursuant to the rules and regulations adopted by the state board of natural resources or as so designated pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 44-10-20 et seq., the Georgia Historic Preservation Act. Landmark museum building means a historic building or structure used as an exhibit of the building or structure itself, which exhibits a high degree of architectural integrity, and which is open to the public not less than 12 days per year; provided, however, that additional uses, original or ancillary, to the use as a museum shall be permitted within the same building, subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13(b)(3). Landmark museum buildings shall be so designated by the state historic preservation officer pursuant to rules and regulations adopted by the state board of natural resources. (Prior Code, § 30-2) Sec. 26-3. - Conditions for application. The provisions of this chapter authorize the building inspector to permit the repair, alteration, addition or change of use or occupancy of existing buildings without total compliance with any rule, regulation, code or standard for new construction requirements under the following general conditions: (1) All noted conditions hazardous to life, based on the provisions of applicable state and local standards or codes for existing buildings and outlined in section 26-4, shall be corrected to a reasonable and realistic degree as set forth in this chapter; (2) The existing building becomes compliant with the minimum performance standard; and (3) The degree of compliance of the building after changes must not be below that existing before the changes. Nothing in this chapter will either require or prohibit compliance with requirements more stringent than those provided in this chapter. (Prior Code, § 30-4) Sec. 26-4. - Hazardous conditions. With reference to existing buildings, the building inspector or his/her authorized designee should assure that any of the following conditions or defects are identified and corrected as he/she deems appropriate and through the utilization of appropriate compliance alternatives: (1) Structural. Any building or structure or portion thereof which is in imminent danger of collapse because of, but not limited to the following factors: a. Dilapidation, deterioration or decay; b. Faulty structural design or construction; c. The removal, movement or instability of any portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of supporting such building; or d. The deterioration, decay or inadequacy of the foundation. (2) Number of exits. Less than two approved independent, remote and properly protected exitways serving every story of a building, except where a single exit way is permitted by the applicable state or local fire code, building code or life safety code. (3) Capacity of exits. Any required door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other required means of egress which is not of sufficient capacity to provide for the population of the portions of the building served and which is not so arranged as to provide safe and adequate means of egress to a place of safety. (4) Mechanical systems. Utilities and mechanical systems not in conformance with the codes in effect at the time of construction of a building which create a serious threat of fire or threaten the safety of the occupants of the building. (Prior Code, § 30-5) Sec. 26-5. - Additions to existing building. Additions to an existing building shall comply with the applicable requirements of state and local laws, rules, regulations, codes, and standards for new construction. Such additions shall not impose loads, either vertical or horizontal, which would cause the existing building to be subjected to stresses exceeding those permitted under new construction. If the existing building does not comply with the standards provided in this chapter and the building inspector finds that the addition adversely affects the performance of the total building, the building inspector may require: (1) The new addition to be separated from the existing structure by at least a two-hour firewall with openings therein properly protected; (2) The installation of an approved automatic fire suppression system; or (3) Other remedies which he/she may deem appropriate. (Prior Code, § 30-6) Sec. 26-6. - Minor alterations and new mechanical systems. Minor alterations or repairs to an existing building which do not adversely affect the performance or safety of the building may be made with the same or like materials. Existing buildings which, in part or as a whole, exceed the requirements of any applicable construction or fire safety code may, in the course of compliance with this chapter, have reduced or removed, in part or total, features not required by such code for new construction; provided, however, that such features were not a condition of prior approval. An existing building or structure which, in part or as a whole, does not meet the requirements of any applicable code for new construction may be altered or repaired without further compliance to any such code by utilizing the provisions of this chapter, provided such building's present degree of compliance to any applicable construction or fire safety code is not reduced. Any new mechanical systems installed in an existing building shall conform to applicable codes for new construction to the fullest extent practical as approved by the building inspector. (Prior Code, § 30-7) Sec. 26-7. - Continued use. The legal use and occupancy of any building or structure may be continued without change, except as may be provided otherwise by this chapter or as may be legally provided by any applicable state or local law, ordinance, rule, regulation, code, or standard. (Prior Code, § 30-8) Sec. 26-8. - Change in use. (a) A total change in the use or occupancy of an existing building which would cause a greater hazard to the public shall not be made unless such building is made to comply with the requirements of applicable state and local rules, regulations, codes, and standards for the new use or occupancy; provided, however, that the compliance alternative provisions of this chapter may be utilized by the building inspector or his/her designee where total or strict compliance with applicable state or local rules, regulations, codes, or standards is not practical. (b) When the proposed use is of equal or lesser hazard, as determined by the building inspector or his/her designee, further compliance with any code for new construction is not required unless otherwise provided in this chapter. Alterations or repairs to an existing building or structure which do not adversely affect the performance of the building may be made with like materials. Any proposed change to the existing building or change in type of contents of the existing building shall not increase the fire hazard to adjacent buildings or structures. If the fire hazard to adjacent buildings or structures is increased, then requirements of applicable construction or fire safety codes for exterior walls shall apply. (Prior Code, § 30-9) Sec. 26-9. - Change in use of a portion of a building. (a) If a portion of a building is changed to a new use or occupancy and that portion is separated from the remainder of the building with vertical or horizontal fire separations complying with applicable state or local rules, regulations, codes, or standards or with compliance alternatives, then the portion changed shall be made to comply to the applicable requirements for the new use or occupancy to the extent noted in section 26-8. (b) If a portion of the building is changed to a new use or occupancy and that portion is not separated from the remainder of the building as noted in subsection (a) of this section, then the provisions of the applicable state and local rules, regulations, codes, and standards applying to each use or occupancy of the building shall apply to the entire building to the extent noted in section 26-8; provided, however, if there are conflicting provisions in requirements for the various uses or occupancies, the building inspector or his/her designee shall apply the strictest requirements. (Prior Code, § 30-10) Sec. 26-10. - Floor loading. Any proposed change in the use or occupancy of an existing building or portion thereof which could increase the floor loading should be investigated by a state registered professional engineer to determine the adequacy of the existing floor system to support the increased loads. If the existing floor system is found to be inadequate, it shall be modified to support the increased loads or the proposed allowable floor loading shall be reduced by and posted by the building inspector or his/her designee. (Prior Code, § 30-11) Sec. 26-11. - Documentation. Whenever action is taken on any existing building to repair, make alterations, or change the use or occupancy of an existing structure and such action proposes the use of compliance alternatives, the building inspector shall ensure that at least one copy of the accepted compliance alternatives approved, including applicable plans, test data, or other data submitted for evaluation, be maintained on file in the office of the building inspector. If such structure also falls under the jurisdiction of a state-level enforcement authority, at least one copy of such materials shall be maintained on file with such state-level authority. (Prior Code, § 30-12) Sec. 26-12. - Compliance alternatives. (a) Subsections (a)(1) through (a)(5) of this section contain generally acceptable compliance alternatives illustrating principles which shall be applied to the rehabilitation of existing buildings by the building inspector in the city. (1) Compliance alternatives for an inadequate number of exits include, but are not limited to, the following: a. Providing connecting fire exit balconies acceptable to the building inspector between buildings; b. Providing alternate exit or egress facilities leading to safety outside the building or to a place of safe refuge in the building or an adjoining building as acceptable to the building inspector; c. Providing exterior fire escapes, as acceptable to the building inspector, where the providing of enclosed interior or enclosed exterior stairs is not practical; or d. Installing early fire warning and fire suppression systems. (2) Compliance alternatives for excessive travel distances to an approved exit include, but are not limited to, the following: a. Installing an approved smoke detection system throughout the building; b. Installing an approved complete automatic fire suppression system; c. Subdividing the exit travel route with smoke-stop doors acceptable to the building inspector; d. Increasing the fire resistance rating of corridor walls and doors; or e. Providing additional approved means of escape. (3) Compliance alternatives for unenclosed or improperly enclosed exit stairways or vertical shafts include, but are not limited to, the following: a. Improving enclosure of exit stairway; b. Adding a partial fire suppression system; c. Adding a sprinkler draft curtain; or d. Adding a smoke detection system. (4) Compliance alternatives for inadequate or a total lack of fire partitions or fire separation walls shall be as set forth in subsection (a)(3) of this section. (5) Compliance alternatives for a lack of required protection of openings in exterior walls where a fire exposure is a risk include, but are not limited to, the following: a. Improving fire resistance of existing openings and protecting them with fire-rated windows or doors, as appropriate; b. Sealing the openings with fire-rated construction, as approved by the building inspector; or c. Installing an approved fire suppression system. (b) Any consideration of the compliance alternatives provided in subsection (a) of this section should take into account all existing and proposed conditions to determine their acceptability. The compliance alternatives are not all-inclusive and do not preclude consideration and approval of other alternatives by the building inspector or his/her designee. (Prior Code, § 30-13) Sec. 26-13. - Right of appeal. (a) When it is contended that a decision of the building inspector is erroneous or that the true intent and meaning of this chapter has been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of the building concerning which decision is made or such owner's duly authorized agent may appeal the decision of the building inspector to the board of adjustments and appeals. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within 90 days after the decision is rendered by the building inspector, and shall be on forms provided by the building inspector. (b) For a building which, in the opinion of the building inspector, is unsafe or dangerous, the building inspector may, at his/her discretion, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. (c) The board of adjustments and appeals, when so appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of this chapter to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this chapter or the public interest, or when, in its opinion, the decision of the building inspector should be modified or reversed. (d) The board of adjustments and appeals shall, in every case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Each decision of the board of adjustments and appeals shall also include the reasons for such decision. If a decision of the board of adjustments and appeals reverses or modifies a refusal, order, or disallowance of the building inspector or varies the application of any provision of this chapter, the building inspector shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. (e) Every decision of the board of adjustments and appeals shall be final, subject, however to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. (Prior Code, § 30-14) Sec. 26-14. - Liability. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to constitute a waiver of the sovereign immunity of the city or any officer or employee thereof in carrying out the provisions of this chapter. Furthermore, no action shall be maintained against the city or any duly authorized elected or appointive officer or duly authorized employee thereof for damages sustained as a result of any fire or hazard covered by this chapter by reason of inspection or other action taken or not taken pursuant to this chapter. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to relieve any property owner, lessee or person in charge thereof from any legal duty, obligation, or liability incident to the ownership, maintenance, or use of such property. (Prior Code, § 30-15) Sec. 26-15. - Landmark museum buildings. (a) The provisions of this section shall apply only to those portions of such buildings which meet all the requirements of a landmark museum building, except as otherwise provided herein, and shall, unless otherwise provided, preempt all laws, regulations, or rules governing reconstruction, alteration, repair, or maintenance of landmark museum buildings.
