(Prior Code, § 42-5) Sec. 30-30. - Scope and applicability. (a) Authority and scope. (1) This chapter is enacted pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17, as amended. (2) The scope and purpose of this chapter shall be as specified in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7. (3) All powers and authorities granted to public officers and public authorities by O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17 are hereby incorporated by reference so as to be assumed, delegated and granted pursuant to this chapter. (b) Applicability. The provisions of this article shall apply to both residential and nonresidential property, whether being occupied or not and whether being developed or not. (Prior Code, § 42-7; Ord. of 10-6-1992, §1; Ord. of 11-2-1999, §1) Secs. 30-31—30-48. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED CONDITIONS AND ABATEMENT PROCEDURES
Sec. 30-49. - Unsafe building or structure. (a) Any building or structure that has any of the following conditions, such that the life, health, property, or safety of its occupants or of the general public are endangered, is hereby declared illegal: (1) Any means of egress or portion thereof that is not of adequate size or is not arranged to provide a safe path of travel in case of fire or panic. (2) Any means of egress or portion thereof, including, but not limited to, a fire door, closing device and fire resistive rating, which is in disrepair or in a dilapidated or nonworking condition such that the means of egress could be rendered unsafe in case of fire or panic. (3) The stress in any material, member or portion thereof, due to all imposed loads, including dead loads, exceeds the stresses allowed in the state building code for new buildings. (4) The building, structure or portion thereof has been damaged by fire, flood, earthquake, wind or other cause to the extent that the structural integrity of the building or structure is less than it was prior to damage and is less than the minimum requirement established by the state building code for new buildings. (5) Any exterior appendage or portion of the building or structure is not securely fastened, attached or anchored such that it would be capable of resisting wind, seismic or similar loads as required by the state building code for new buildings. (6) The building, structure or portion thereof is, for any reason, manifestly unsafe or unsanitary for the purpose for which it is being used. (7) The building, structure or portion thereof, as a result of decay, deterioration or dilapidation, is likely to fully or partially collapse. (8) The building, structure or portion thereof has been constructed or maintained in violation of a specific requirement of the standard codes or of a city, county or state law. (9) The building, structure or portion thereof is in such a condition as to constitute a public nuisance. (10) The building, structure or portion thereof is unsafe or unsanitary, is not provided with adequate egress, constitutes a fire hazard, is otherwise a danger to human life, or which, in relation to existing use, constitutes a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence or abandonment. (b) Any illegal building or structure under subsection (a) of this section shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation or demolition or qualify for a secured building status in accordance with this division (Prior Code, § 42-9) Sec. 30-50. - Procedures and requirements to secure buildings and structures. The following procedures and requirements must be met in order to secure buildings and structures: (1) The owner must apply for a secured building/structure permit and pay the required fees, and the public officer and/or building official must then inspect such structure. (2) To qualify for secured building status, the building must be structurally sound, including the walls and roof; otherwise, the secured building permit will be denied. (3) If the building is structurally sound, nonstructural interior portions (electrical wiring, plumbing, etc.) need not comply with appropriate codes while in secured status. (4) The building or structure must remain vacant while in secured status. (5) All utilities must remain turned off while in secured status. (6) The building must be secured, which includes, but is not limited to, windows and doors covered and secured. (7) Structures referenced in the state building code other than buildings must be repaired, rehabilitated, secured or demolished. (8) Buildings or structures on secured status shall be placed on a special routing slip for fire and police departments. a. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or be inside a secured building or structure, except for the owner or duly authorized agent. b. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove securing material on a secured building or structure. (9) The building or structure must be annually reinspected by a public officer and/or building official. A report detailing the inspector's findings shall be included in the case file. If compliance is not present at the time of such inspection, renewal of the secured building/structure permit will be forfeited and abatement of the nuisance will be referred to the city commission for necessary action. (10) A secured building permit may be renewed annually upon payment of the fee by the owner. (Prior Code, § 42-10) Sec. 30-51. - Reoccupying a secured building or structure. Before a building or structure can be reoccupied, the following are required: (1) The building or structure must be fully returned to compliance with building/fire codes; (2) The building or structure must be reinspected by the public officer and/or building official; (3) Approval of required plans, if applicable, historic preservation, if applicable, request and purchase of all required building permits, subtrade permits, etc., as may be required, for compliance with construction codes; and (4) No utilities shall be turned on until the building or structure is in full compliance with construction codes; provided that temporary service is permitted if necessary for construction work to bring such building or structure back in to compliance with construction codes. (Prior Code, § 42-11) Sec. 30-52. - Complaint and inspection. (a) Complaint. (1) Whenever a request is filed with the housing official by a public authority or by at least two unrelated residents of the city that any dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use, or whenever it appears to the housing official (on his/her own motion) that any dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use or is vacant, dilapidated and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, the housing official shall, if his/her preliminary investigation discloses a basis for such charges, issue and cause to be served upon the owner of and any parties in interest in such dwelling, building, or structure a complaint stating the charges in that respect and containing a notice that a hearing will be held before the administrative hearing officer, who shall be a person other than the city manager or code enforcement officer and shall be designated by the city manager, at a place within the city, fixed not less than ten or more than 30 days after the serving of such complaint. (2) The owner and any parties in interest shall be given the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person or otherwise and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the complaint. (3) The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in hearings before the administrative hearing officer. (4) If, after such notice and hearing, the administrative hearing officer determines that the dwelling, building or structure under consideration is unfit for human habitation, is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use or is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes, he/she shall state in writing his/her findings of fact in support of such determination and shall issue and cause to be served upon the owner thereof an order requiring the owners or parties in interest, within the time specified in the order, to: a. Repair, alter or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to render it fit for human habitation or for current commercial, industrial, or business use or to vacate and close the dwelling, building or structure as a human habitation; or b. Remove or demolish such dwelling, building, or structure if the repair, alteration, or improvement of such dwelling, building, or structure cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the dwelling, building, or structure. In no event shall the city require removal or demolition of any dwelling, building, or structure except upon a finding that the cost of repair, alteration, or improvement thereof exceeds one-half the value such dwelling, building, or structure will have when repaired to satisfy the minimum requirements of this chapter. (b) Records. The city clerk shall be the supervisor and custodian of the records on the property against which a complaint is issued, including, but not limited to, the investigation findings, course of action required, and, if applicable, citations and court findings. Such records shall be public records and made available to any party in interest, and copies thereof shall be provided upon the payment of such reasonable cost as may be incurred in duplicating or otherwise providing them. Such records shall be preserved for not less than four years after the proceedings and action, if any, regarding the property are concluded. (Prior Code, § 42-12) Sec. 30-53. - Failure to comply with order to vacate and close or to demolish. (a) If the owner or parties in interest fail to comply with an order to vacate and close or demolish a dwelling, building, or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be repaired, altered, or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished and may cause to be posted on the main entrance of such building, dwelling, or structure so closed a placard with the following words: "This building/structure is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use; the use or occupation of this building/structure for human habitation or for commercial industrial, or business use is prohibited and unlawful." (b) If the owner fails to comply with any order to remove or demolish a dwelling, building, or structure, the public officer may cause such dwelling, building, or structure to be removed or demolished; provided, however, that the duties of the public officer set forth in this subsection shall not be exercised until the city commission shall have by ordinance ordered the public officer to proceed to effectuate the purpose of this chapter and of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17, with respect to the particular property which the public officer has found to be unfit for human habitation or unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use, as described in this chapter. (c) The placard described in subsection (a) of this section shall bear the date posted, the street number of the building involved, and the signature of the housing official. It shall thereafter be unlawful for such placard to be mutilated or removed or for such building to be occupied until the required corrective action is taken. (Prior Code, §§ 42-13, 42-14; Ord. of 10-6-1992; Ord. of 11-2-1999, §4) Sec. 30-54. - Demolition. No person shall begin demolition until a permit for demolition has been obtained and all utilities have been cut off and capped at the street. The person who has secured the permit shall remove from the property all debris, trash, litter, rubbish, rubble and foundation exposed above the ground level, fill any excavation or other depressions to existing grade with clean dirt containing no more than 25 percent stone or masonry, and adequately slope and drain all filled areas as determined by the director of the building inspection department. (Prior Code, § 42-15; Ord. of 10-6-1992, §1) Secs. 30-55—30-111. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OTHER PUBLIC NUISANCES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 30-112. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to exercise the police power in relation to public nuisances and abatement of such nuisances, to protect the public health, safety and welfare, and to promote the economic development of the city. It is also the purpose of this article to prevent and prohibit those conditions which reduce the value of private property, interfere with enjoyment of public and private property, create and constitute fire and other safety and health hazards, and generally create a menace to the health and welfare of the public and contribute to the degradation of the character of neighborhoods and depreciation of property values. It is necessary for the public health, safety and welfare to regulate, prevent and prohibit conditions which may constitute disorderly, disturbing, unsafe, unsanitary, fly-producing, rat-harboring and/or disease-causing places, conditions or objects. It is also necessary for the public, social and economic welfare to regulate, prevent and prohibit conditions that degrade the city's scenic attractiveness and livability and its economic development. (Prior Code, § 48-1; Ord. of 2-4-2003) Sec. 30-113. - Types of nuisances. Each of the following places, conditions or things is declared to constitute a public nuisance, and whenever the housing official determines that any of these conditions exist upon any premises, such officer may require or provide for the abatement thereof pursuant to this article: (1) Stagnant water on premises; (2) Any dead or decaying matter, weeds, vegetation or any fruit, vegetable, animal or rodent upon premises which is odorous or capable of causing disease or annoyance to the inhabitants of the city; (3) The generation of smoke and fumes in sufficient amount to cause an odor or annoyance to the inhabitants of the city; (4) The pollution of public water or the injection of matter into the sewage system which is damaging thereto; (5) Maintaining a dangerous or diseased animal or fowl; (6) Obstruction of a public street, highway or sidewalk without a permit; (7) Loud or unusual noises which are detrimental or annoying to the public, including, without limitation, unusual loud disturbances in or around churches or multiple-family complexes such as loud music and other activities in swimming pool and clubhouse areas; (8) All walls, trees, building or other structures that may endanger persons or property; (9) Any business or building where illegal activities are habitually and commonly conducted in such a manner as to reasonably suggest that the owner or operator of the business or building is aware of the illegal activities and has failed to reasonably attempt to prevent such activities; (10) Unused iceboxes, refrigerators and the like, unless the doors, latches or locks thereof are removed; (11) Any trees, shrubbery or other plants or parts thereof which obstruct clear, safe vision on roadways and intersections of the city; (12) Any premises, dwelling unit or other structure, place or vacant lot permitted to deteriorate in appearance or condition so as to be degrading to the surrounding premises; (13) The keeping of used or dilapidated furniture, appliances, machinery, bicycles, automobiles, automobile parts and other toys, junk, debris or other equipment, that are either in an inoperable condition or are wholly or partially wrecked, junked, or dismantled, upon premises which are not completely enclosed within a building; (14) Tall grass, weeds and bushes, other undergrowth, and trash and debris of any type upon the premises of any dwelling unit or other structure, place or vacant lot; (15) The slaughtering and butchering of animals, except when done in an enclosed area free from public view; (16) Any outdoor lighting which is detrimental or annoying to the public or directly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of surrounding residential premises; and (17) Any other condition constituting a nuisance under state law. (Prior Code, § 48-2) Secs. 30-114—30-139. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED CONDUCT AND ABATEMENT PROCEDURES
Sec. 30-140. - Property maintenance standards. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property within the city to have, place or allow the existence of any of the following on such premises to the extent and in a manner that could threaten or endanger the health, safety and welfare or could adversely affect and impair the economic value of adjacent property: (1) Any accumulation of litter, debris, refuse, garbage, garden trash, rubbish or animal excrement on any front, side or rear yard or any porch, underneath any building or in any accessory building; (2) Any objects, including, but not limited to, junk materials, machinery and equipment, appliances or other household items, building materials or piles of dirt in the front yard of any property or on a front porch of any structure located thereon; (3) Any objects, including, but not limited to, junk materials, machinery and equipment, appliances or other household items, building materials or piles of dirt on the side or rear yards, or on side or rear porches or underneath any building or in any accessory building that is visible from a street, unless stored in an enclosed building; (4) Any overgrown grass or weeds of a height six inches or more or any other unkempt vegetation in any yard, front, side or rear, of all improved property of two acres or less, or any overgrown grass or weeds of a height 12 inches or more or any other unkempt vegetation in any yard, front, side or rear, of all unimproved property of less than two acres or improved property larger than two acres, except that grass areas abutting and within 50 feet of any city street shall be maintained at a height not exceeding six inches; (5) Any storage building on the front yard or any dilapidated storage building on the side or rear yard; (6) Any automobile, truck or vehicle tires on the front, rear or side of any property for a period exceeding 45 days, unless stored in an enclosed building; (7) Any clothesline or other outdoor apparatus used for the drying of clothes or other fabrics used for household or business use in the front yard of any residence or business. (8) Property owners shall be prohibited from allowing kudzu (pueraria lobata) to grow on their property within ten feet of any adjacent property line or right-of-way. (b) It shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow an automotive vehicle, boat or trailer-type vehicle on the front yard of any city property unless placed on an established paved or graveled driveway. (c) It shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle or derelict boat or trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on a front yard or the established paved or gravel driveway of a front yard, and it shall be unlawful to place, keep, store or allow to remain any derelict automotive vehicle or derelict boat or trailer-type vehicle or parts thereof on the side or rear yards of any city property if visible from a street or adjoining property unless contained in a properly enclosed and roofed accessory building which meets all appropriate zoning requirements of the city. For purposes of this section, the term "derelict automobile, boat or trailer-type vehicle" means a vehicle that is not operable due to lack of repairs or is unsafe to operate due to lack of repairs or damage and/or which constitutes a nuisance pursuant to this article. (Prior Code, § 49-1; Ord. of 2-4-2003; Ord. No. 09-18-01, § 1, 10-2-2018) Sec. 30-141. - Prohibited conduct. It is unlawful for any responsible person to create, permit, maintain, suffer, carry on or allow upon his/her premises any of the acts or things declared by this article to be a public nuisance. Any person creating, keeping or maintaining a nuisance, or permitting, allowing or suffering any nuisance to be maintained who neglects or fails to abate or remove the nuisance within 24 hours next after so creating, keeping, maintaining or permitting, allowing or suffering the same to be maintained such nuisance, shall, for each 24 hours thereafter during which the nuisance is continued, be guilty of a separate offense of maintaining a public nuisance. (Prior Code, § 48-3) Sec. 30-142. - Abatement—Order. (a) Upon the discovery of a nuisance, the housing official may order the responsible person creating, keeping, maintaining or permitting the same to abate such nuisance, and in default thereof, to undertake the abatement on behalf of the city. At least ten days before commencing abatement, except in those cases of immediate necessity, the officer shall notify the person creating, keeping, maintaining or permitting the nuisance, the property owner and any person in possession of the property, if known, of his/her intentions. The notice shall be served personally or by first class mail and shall describe with particularity the nature of the violation and the sections of this Code or other laws which are being violated and shall specify a reasonable time within which the abatement must be accomplished. The expenses of such abatement may be recoverable as provided in chapter 1. (b) In addition to such other penalties as may be imposed, a court entering a judgment of guilty to a charge of creating a public nuisance may order the abatement of the same on such terms and conditions as may be just and equitable. (Prior Code, § 48-4) Sec. 30-143. - Same—Immediate. Whenever any nuisance is within a public way or easement or is of such a character and so situated that it can be abated without the invasion or destruction of property or the prejudice of any right, and the further continuance is likely to result in expense to the city or injury to any person or property, and the responsible person cannot be contacted or refuses to immediately abate the condition, the enforcement officer may abate and remove the nuisance summarily. The expenses of such abatement may be recoverable as provided in chapter 1. (Prior Code, § 48-5) Sec. 30-144. - Same—By city; safeguards. In any case where a nuisance is to be abated by the enforcement officer, it shall be the duty of such officer to proceed with the due care and without unnecessary destruction of property. He/she shall in all cases be authorized to employ such assistance and adopt such means as may be necessary to effect the entire abatement of the nuisance. (Prior Code, § 48-6) Sec. 30-145. - Complaint of nuisance. Any city official or inhabitant of the city may file a verified complaint of a public nuisance with the city office of code enforcement. A housing official shall thereupon issue a citation to the offender to appear in municipal court to hear and determine the existence of such nuisance and, if such nuisance is found to exist, to order its abatement. A finding by any governmental health department, health officer or a building inspector, or housing official that any property, dwelling, building or structure is a health or safety hazard shall constitute prima facie evidence that such property and/or person is in violation of this article. (Prior Code, § 48-7) Secs. 30-146—30-170. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 30-171. - Lien on property. The cost of vacating, securing, removing, closing, demolition, and/or the cutting of undesirable vegetation by the city shall be a lien for such amount against the real property upon which the cost was incurred. The lien shall attach to the real property upon the payment of all costs of action against the property by the city and the filing of an itemized statement of the total sum of such costs by the housing official in the office of the city commission on a lien docket maintained for such purpose. If the dwelling, building, or structure is removed or demolished as directed by the housing official, the housing official shall sell the materials of such dwelling, building, or structure and shall credit the proceeds of such sale against the cost of the removal or demolition, and any balance remaining shall be deposited in the superior court by the housing official, secured in such manner as may be directed by such court, and disbursed by such court to the persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of such court. (Prior Code, §§ 42-16, 48-8) Sec. 30-172. - Procedure for collection of amount due on lien. The city shall enforce the collection of any amount due on a lien arising under this chapter in the following manner: (1) Amount. The amount of the lien shall be established as follows: a. The cost of administration to be assessed against properties and service shall be on a schedule available in the city clerk's office. b. The cost of vacating, securing, removing, closing or demolishing any property shall be the cost paid or incurred by the city in effecting action against such property. (2) Notice of lien. The owner and/or parties in interest in the property shall be served with a copy of the lien and shall be allowed to satisfy the amount due on such lien by paying to the city, within 30 days after the perfection of such lien, a sum of money not less than 25 percent of the total due on such lien, and by further paying the remaining balance due, together with interest at the rate of one percent per month, in which shall become due and payable on the anniversary date of the initial payment made as prescribed in this subsection. (3) Transfer of property. Should the property upon which such lien is perfected be sold, transferred or conveyed by the owner and/or parties in interest at any time prior to the termination of the three-year payment period, the entire lien, with earned interest, shall be due and payable to the city. (4) Nonsatisfaction. Should the amount due on such lien or any portion thereof be unpaid after the passage of such three-year period, or upon the occurrence of the contingency provided for in subsection (3) of this section, the city may enforce the collection of any amount due on such lien in the same manner as provided in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358 and other applicable state statutes. This procedure shall be subject to the right of redemption by any person having any right, title, or interest in or lien upon such property, all as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-4-40 et seq. (Prior Code, §§ 42-17, 48-8) Sec. 30-173. - Notices and orders. (a) Service upon parties in interest and owners of unfit buildings or structures. (1) Complaints or orders issued by a public officer pursuant to this chapter shall, in all cases, be served upon each person in possession of such property, each owner, and each party in interest, and the return of service signed by the public officer or his/her agent or an affidavit of service executed by any citizen of the state reciting that a copy of such complaint or orders was served upon each person in possession of such property, each owner, and each party in interest personally or such copy having been left at the place of his/her residence shall be sufficient evidence as to the service of such person in possession, owner, and party in interest. (2) If any owner or party in interest resides outside the city, service shall be perfected by causing a copy of such complaint or orders to be served upon such party by the sheriff or any lawful deputy of the county of the residence of such party, or such service may be made by any citizen, and the return of such sheriff or lawful deputy of the affidavit of such citizen that such party was served, either personally or by a copy of the complaint or orders having been left at the residence of such party shall be conclusive as to such service. (3) Nonresidents of the state shall be served by a copy of such complaint or orders being posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the complaint or orders. Where the address of such nonresident is known, a copy of such complaint or orders shall be mailed to such resident by registered or certified mail. (4) In the event either the owner or any party in interest is a minor, an insane person or person laboring under disabilities, the guardian or other personal representative of such person shall be served such complaint or orders, and if such guardian or personal representative resides outside the city or is a nonresident of the state, he/she shall be served as provided for in subsection (3) of this section or as provided in this subsection in such cases. If such minor or insane person or person laboring under disabilities has no guardian or personal representative or in the event such minor or insane person lives outside the city or is a nonresident of this state, service shall be perfected by serving such minor or insane person, personally or by leaving a copy at the place of his/her residence, which shall be sufficient evidence as to the service of such person; in the case of other persons who live outside of the city or are nonresidents, service shall be perfected by serving the judge of the probate court of the county, who shall stand in the place of and protect the rights of such minor or insane person or appoint a guardian ad litem for such person. (5) In the event the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest are unknown and cannot be ascertained by the public officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence and the public officer has made an affidavit to that effect, the service of such complaint or order upon such person shall be made in the same manner as provided in subsection (3) of this section, or service may be perfected upon any person holding itself out as an agent for the property involved. (6) A copy of such complaint or orders shall also be filed in the real estate records of the office of the clerk of the superior court, along with a lis pendens notice, and such filing of the complaint or orders shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. Any such complaint or orders and an appropriate lis pendens notice shall contain a statement to the effect that a lien may arise against the described property and that an itemized statement of such lien is maintained on a lien docket maintained by the city commission. (b) Costs. The costs of service pursuant to this section shall be included in the sums otherwise due under this chapter. (c) Service. Such person designated by the city who is of legal age may be authorized to perform the service of documents pursuant to this division in the manner usually performed by the sheriff, provided such person follows the procedures established by state law for such officials, and a fee may be assessed against the property so long as such fee does not exceed the fee currently imposed by the sheriff of the county for such activity. (d) Failure to answer notice or order. If the owner and parties in interest neither file an answer to the complaint or cause compliance and a decision is rendered which affects the property, an advertisement shall be published in the newspaper utilized for the county sheriff's tax sales for two consecutive weeks. The advertisement shall include the action required as pertaining to the property and the consequences which may result from noncompliance with this chapter or such notice. A notice may identify more than one property. (Prior Code, § 42-18; Ord. of 10-6-1992, §1; Ord. of 11-2-1999, §§ 7, 8) Secs. 30-174—30-204. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - NOISE REGULATIONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-12-02, adopted Aug. 7, 2012, set out provisions intended for use as §§ 30-5—30-10. For purposes clarity, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as art. V, §§ 30-205—30-210.
Sec. 30-205. - Definitions. Definitions of technical terms used which are not herein defined shall be obtained from publications of acoustical terminology issued by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) as its successor body. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: (1) Ambient sound level means the noise associated with a given environment, exclusive of a particular noise being tested, being usually a composite of sounds from many sources near and far, exclusive of intruding noises from isolated identifiable sources. (2) A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level is designated dB(A) or dBA. (3) Construction means any site preparation, assembly, erection, substantial repair, alteration, or similar action for or of public or private right-of-way, structures, utilities, or similar properties. (4) Decibel (dB) means a logarithmic and dimensionless unit of measure used in describing the relative loudness of level of sound. (5) Demolition means any dismantling, intentional destruction or removal of structures, utilities, public, or private right-of-way surfaces, or similar property. (6) Emergency means any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical or psychological trauma or property damage which demands immediate action. (7) Emergency work means any work performed for the purposes of alleviating or resolving an emergency. (8) Impulsive sound means a sound of short duration, usually less than one second, with an abrupt onset and rapid decay. Examples of sources of impulsive sound include explosions, drop forge impacts, and the discharge of firearms. (9) Motor vehicle means any motor-operated vehicle licensed for use on the public highways, but not including a motorcycle. (10) Motorcycle means any motor vehicle having a saddle or seat for the use of the rider and designated to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground. The term shall include, but not be limited to, motorized bicycles and motor scooters. (11) Noise means any sound which disturbs humans or which causes or tends to cause an adverse psychological or physiological effect on humans. (12) Noise control officer means the person designated by the city having responsibility for the enforcement of any provision of this article. (13) Noise disturbance means any sound which endangers or injures the welfare, safety or health of human beings, or disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities, or devalues or injures personal or real property, or is hereinafter defined. (14) Noise sensitive activities means activities which should be conducted under conditions of exceptional quiet including, but not limited to, operation of schools, libraries open to the public, churches, hospitals, and nursing homes. (15) Noise sensitive areas means any area designated for the purpose of ensuring exceptional quiet and clearly posted with "Noise Sensitive Area" signs, because of the noise sensitive activities conducted therein. (16) Person means any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility operative, state agency, municipality or other political subdivisions of this state, any interstate body, or any other legal entity. (17) Powered model vehicle means any self-propelled airborne, waterborne, or land-borne model plane, vessel, or vehicle, which is not designed to carry persons including, but not limited to, any model airplane, boat, car or rocket. (18) Public right-of-way means any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, sidewalk, lane or similar place which is owned or controlled by a government entity. (19) Public space means any real property, including any structure thereon, which is owned or controlled by a governmental entity. (20) Pure tone means any sound which can be distinctly heard as a single pitch or a set of single pitches. (21) Real property boundary means an imaginary line along the ground surface, and its vertical extension, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, but not including intra-building real property divisions. (22) Receiving land use means the use or occupancy of the property from which a complaint is made concerning noise which received the transmission of sound as hereinafter defined, however, the allowable decibel levels are based on the zoning district as opposed to the use of the receiving land. (23) Residential means any property on which is located a building or structure used wholly or partially for living or sleeping purposes. (24) Sound means an oscillation in pressure, particle displacement, partial velocity or other physical parameter, in a medium with internal forces that cause compression and rarefaction of that medium. The description of sound may include any characteristic of such sound, including duration, intensity and frequency. (25) Sound level means the weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of a sound level meter and frequency weighting network, such as A, B, or C as specified in American National Standards Institute Specifications for Sound Level Meters (ANSI S1.41983, or the latest approved revision thereof). If the frequency weighting employed is not indicated, the A-weighting shall apply. (26) Sound level meter means an instrument which includes a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector, integrator or time average, output or display meter, and weighting networks used to measure sound pressure levels, which complies with American National Standards Institute Standard 1.4-1983, as revised. (27) Sound pressure means the instantaneous difference between the actual pressure and the average or barometric pressure at a given point in space, as produced by sound energy. (Ord. No. 07-12-02, 8-7-2012) Sec. 30-206. - Exceptions. The provisions of this article shall not apply to: (1) The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the existence of an emergency. (2) The emission of sound in the performance of emergency work. (3) Public mass transportation vehicles. (4) Church or clock carillons, bells or chimes. (5) The emission of sound in the discharge of weapons or in fireworks displays for which a permit has been issued. (6) Public works projects specifically approved by the mayor and commission. (Ord. No. 07-12-02, 8-7-2012) Sec. 30-207. - Noise disturbance prohibited. (a) No person shall make, continue, or cause to be made or continued, except as permitted, any noise disturbance, or any noise in excess of the limits for such noise established in this section. (b) With the exception of sound levels elsewhere specifically authorized by this article, table 1 sets forth the maximum permissible sound levels allowed at or within the real property boundary of a receiving land use. Any activity or use that produces a sound in excess of such noise levels for a receiving land use shall be deemed a noise disturbance and is in violation of this article. (c) The measurement of sound or noise shall be made with a sound level meter meeting the standards prescribed by the American National Standards Institute or its successor body. The instrument shall be maintained in calibration and good working order. Octave band corrections may be employed in meeting the response specification. A calibration check shall be made of the system at the time of any noise measurement. Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation of the noise source. The microphone used during measurement shall be positioned so as not to create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured noise. A windscreen for the microphone shall be used when required. Traffic, other transportation noise sources and other background noises shall not be considered in taking measurements except where such background noise interferes with the primary noise being measured. It is the intention that this sound to be measured is what is being created by the sound complained of excluding intruding noises from isolated identifiable sources, but including ambient sound level. The measure of all sound levels shall be made as to the property line of the receiving land use as is practical. Table 1 Sound Levels by Receiving Land Use
Notes: (1) = As set forth in the zoning ordinance. (2) = Any zoning district containing the letter "R". (3) = Unless otherwise stated in this article. (4) = For any source of sound which emits a pure tone, the maximum sound level limits set shall be reduced by five dBA. (d) Equipment use restrictions. Regardless of decibel levels, the following equipment may not be operated between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Monday—Friday and 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday: (1) Electrical power tools. (2) Construction equipment. (Ord. No. 07-12-02, 8-7-2012) Sec. 30-208. - [Validity; severability.] (a) It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that all sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this article are upon their enactment, believed by the city commission to be fully valid, enforceable and constitutional. (b) It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, each and every section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this article is severable from every other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this article. It is further declared to be the intention of the city commission that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, no section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this article is mutually dependent upon any other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this article. (c) In the event that any section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this article shall, for any reason whatsoever, be declared invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, it is the express intent of the city commission that such invalidity, unconstitutionally or unenforceability shall, to the greatest extent allowed by law, not render invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable any of the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases of this article and that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, all remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases of this article shall remain valid, constitutional, enforceable, and of full force and effect. (Ord. No. 07-12-02, 8-7-2012) Sec. 30-209. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. Except as otherwise provided herein, all ordinance or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 07-12-02, 8-7-2012) Sec. 30-210. - Effective date. The ordinance from which this article derives shall become effective upon its adoption. (Ord. No. 07-12-02, 8-7-2012) Secs. 30-211—30-235. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 32 - PARADES, SPECIAL EVENTS, ETC.[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-10-03, §§ 1—19, adopted Dec. 7 2010, amended ch. 32 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 32, entitled "Parades", §§ 32-1—32-13, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from: Prior Code, §§ 31-1—31-13. State Law reference— Freedom of speech and of the press guaranteed, Ga. Const. art. I, § I, ¶ V; operation of motor vehicles and motorcycles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7.
Sec. 32-1. - Purpose and findings. The Mayor and Commission of the City of Cornelia find that special events as herein defined, are a medium through which individuals may conduct certain lawful economic and non-economic activities on the public properties, streets, sidewalks, and rights-of-way lying within the City of Cornelia, Georgia, and that necessary to the protection of public health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of Cornelia. By enacting this chapter the Mayor and Commission of the City of Cornelia intend to: (1) Balance the rights of individuals, groups, organizations, clubs, associations, or other entities to conduct such special events; (2) Protect the public health, safety, and welfare; (3) Reduce traffic and pedestrian hazards; (4) Reduce the possible adverse effect of such special events on the inhabitants and economic interests located in the City of Cornelia; (5) Protect property values within the City of Cornelia by minimizing the possible adverse effects of such special events; (6) Promote economic development; and (7) Ensure the fair and consistent enforcement of special events regulations. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 1, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-2. - Definitions. Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall be as defined in the most recent edition of the Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary. Words not defined herein or in the above referenced book shall be construed to have the meaning given by common and ordinary use, and shall be interpreted within the context of the sentence, section, and article in which they occur. Words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. Words used in the present tense include the future tense. For the purposes of this chapter, certain words or terms used herein shall be defined as follows: (1) The term "producer" shall mean any person, group of persons, organization, association, club, or other entity responsible for planning, producing and conducting a special event. (2) The term "special event" shall mean any organized activity having as its primary purpose entertainment, recreation and/or education, such as a festival or celebration, foot or vehicle race, parade or march, rally or assembly which takes place on a public property, street, sidewalk or right-of-way, or which occurs on private property and impacts government services on a public property, street, sidewalk or right-of-way. (3) The term "vendor" shall mean any person or persons who engages in the sale to the public of any food or food products, goods, services, or merchandise of whatever nature from any location, either mobile or stationary, on a temporary basis during an approved special event. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 2, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-3. - Applications and permits. (a) Permits required. It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct or cause to be conducted any special event in the City of Cornelia without first obtaining from the City of Cornelia a valid permit for such special event. (b) Geographic limitations. Each special event shall be conducted, located, and limited to the specific geographic area or areas authorized and permitted under the terms, conditions and restrictions of the City of Cornelia permit issued for each such special event and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (c) Time limitations. Each special event shall be limited in time to the dates and time periods authorized and permitted under the terms, conditions, and restrictions of the City of Cornelia permit issued for each such special event and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (d) Activity limitations. Each special event shall be limited to those activities authorized and permitted under the terms, conditions, and restrictions of the City of Cornelia permit issued for each such special event and in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (e) Application. A producer of a special event shall make application for such permit at the Cornelia City Hall in a form prescribed by the City of Cornelia, and file such completed application with the city manager or his designee. Such applications may be obtained from city hall. (f) Application fee. All fees will be published in the city's fee schedule. (g) Applications for special events which request the use of any public property, street, sidewalk, or right-of-way within the City of Cornelia, or for events which occur on private property and impact government services on a public property, street, sidewalk or right-of-way, and which propose more than 25 attendees, shall be filed with the city manager or his designee at least 45 days prior to the date of the event. Applications for special events which request the use of any public property, street, sidewalk, or right-of-way within the City of Cornelia, or for events which occur on private property and impact government services on a public property, street, sidewalk, or right-of-way, and which propose 25 or fewer attendees, shall be filed with the city manager or his designee at least 30 days prior to the date the event is scheduled to occur. However, no application shall be accepted earlier than one year prior to the date of the proposed special event. (h) Permit fee. In addition to the application fee, the producer shall pay a permit fee in order to conduct a special event within the City of Cornelia. The amount of said fee shall be based on the services which the City of Cornelia may elect to provide to the producer of such special event and shall be equal to the estimated actual cost to the City of Cornelia to provide such services. The initial permit fee shall be the aggregate of the estimated costs of such services. If, at the conclusion of the special event, the cost of the services provided by the City of Cornelia is greater than the initial permit fee, the producer of the event shall be billed for the difference. Failure to pay the outstanding amount within 30 days of the billing date shall be a violation of this chapter. The initial permit fee shall be paid in full prior to the issuance of the special event permit for such special event. The application fee and the permit fee specified in this chapter shall be in addition to any other fees which may be required by any other ordinances or regulations of the City of Cornelia which may be applicable. No producer of any special event, except as otherwise provided for, shall be exempt from the payment of the appropriate fees required under this chapter, except as authorized by the Mayor and Commission of the City of Cornelia. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 3, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-4. - Identification of producer. The producer of a special event, be it an individual, group or organization, shall be fully identified on the application. However, a special event permit shall be issued only to an individual person, who shall be the designated agent of any producer who is not an individual, and such individual person shall be solely and fully responsible for compliance with all provisions, including all financial requirements, of this chapter and other applicable laws. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 19, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-5. - Administrative review. The city manager will review each application in order to determine the nature and activities of the proposed event, and to evaluate the effect of such proposed special event on the City of Cornelia, and to determine the amount of the permit fee described in section 32-3 of this chapter. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 5, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-6. - Special restrictions and conditions on permit. After such determination and evaluation by the city manager, the city manager may impose such special conditions or restrictions on said permit as may promote the protection of the public health, safety and welfare of the City of Cornelia, and such special conditions and restrictions so imposed shall be construed to have the full force and effect of law as a provision of this chapter. A violation of any such special conditions or restrictions shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 6, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-7. - Prior permit from the department of transportation. Any special event which is to use a portion of any State of Georgia highway right-of-way lying within the City of Cornelia must also have obtained all required permits from the Georgia Department of Transportation. It shall be the applicant's sole duty and responsibility to obtain all such permits prior to making application to the City of Cornelia for a special event permit. No City of Cornelia special event permit shall be issued without the proper Georgia Department of Transportation permit first having been obtained, and a copy of same filed with the city clerk with the application for the City of Cornelia special event permit. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 7, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-8. - Liability. The producer of any special event shall hold harmless the City of Cornelia, its officers, employees, and agents from any and all liability for damages arising from any acts or omissions emanating from a special event. Proof of such waiver and indemnification shall be filed with and made part of, the application for a special event permit. The producer shall be responsible for providing a $1,000,000.00 certificate of insurance, with the City of Cornelia listed as additional insured and certificate holder at least 14 days prior to the event. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 8, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-9. - Vendors. (a) The sale of food, any merchandise and/or services of any type, by a vendor shall be allowed as a component of a special event permit. It shall be unlawful for any vendor to engage in such business at any location or in any manner not authorized by the City of Cornelia permit. (b) Vendors must obtain a permit from the City of Cornelia Planning Department at least five business days prior to the event. All vendors must display a copy of such permit at all times during the event. (c) Food vendors shall be subject to the applicable rules and regulations governing food service within the City of Cornelia, including, but not limited to the rules and regulations of the Habersham County Health Department. Food vendors shall provide proof of compliance with the Habersham County Health Department rules and regulations prior to the issuance of a permit by the City of Cornelia. (d) It shall be the responsibility of the producer of a special event to assure such compliance by such vendors. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 9, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-10. - Traffic and crowd control. Such traffic and crowd control on public property, streets, sidewalks and rights-of-way lying within the City of Cornelia shall be the responsibility of the producer. A plan for such crowd control must be submitted with the application. The City of Cornelia can provide such crowd control at the request of the vendor for a fee to be determined by the city manager. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 10, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-11. - Toilet facilities. The producer of a special event shall be required to provide toilet facilities at any special event lasting more than three hours at which more than 100 or more persons are expected to be in attendance. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 11, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-12. - Musical entertainment. Musical entertainment shall be provided in a manner consistent with the peace and good order of the City of Cornelia. The producer of the special event shall be responsible for the full compliance with any and all ordinances governing such musical entertainment. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 12, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-13. - Tents, stages and structures. Tents, arbors, stages, grandstands, and other temporary structures and facilities constructed or erected as a part of a permitted special event shall be approved by the City of Cornelia prior to and after construction and erection. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 13, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-14. - Public property closing. No public property, street, sidewalk or right-of-way shall be partially or completely closed as part of a special event unless such closure shall have been authorized in the special event permit issued by the City of Cornelia. Provided however, such closures shall require the prior approval of the Mayor and Commission of the City of Cornelia. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 14, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-15. - Duration of permit. No special event permit issued under this chapter shall be valid prior to or past the date of the special event for which it is issued. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 15, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-16. - Picketing and demonstrations, etc. Any person, group or organization engaged in any picketing, demonstrations, assembly, gathering, procession, or other activity protected by the United States Constitution, shall be prohibited from blocking the ingress and egress of any public or private place within the City of Cornelia, and any such person, group or organization engaged in any picketing, demonstrations, assembly, gathering, procession, or other activity protected by the United States Constitution, may be required under the provisions of this chapter to conduct such protected activities in certain designated areas identified by the City of Cornelia. Any person, group or organization engaged in such protected activities is required to make application as set forth in section 32-3 of this chapter. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 16, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-17. - Funeral processions. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any motorcade conducted under the supervision and direction of a funeral director in conjunction with any funeral. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 17, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-18. - Revocation of permit. If any permitted producer or vendor, and/or an employee, agent, or contractor of such producer or vendor, during the course of the permitted special event, shall violate any law of the United States, the State of Georgia, or any ordinance of the City of Cornelia, and an arrest is made or citation is issued arising out of such violation, the special event permit may be immediately revoked by the city manager or his designee. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 18, 12-7-2010) Sec. 32-19. - Enforcement and penalties. (a) Any person who attempts to conduct a special event without having first obtained the necessary special event permit in the manner provided in this chapter shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as allowed pursuant to chapter 1, section 1-12 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Cornelia. Every day such violation exists shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as herein set out. (b) Action pursuant to any provision of this chapter shall not be a bar to the enforcement of this chapter by injunction or other appropriate remedy, and the City of Cornelia, acting by and through the city manager or his designee, shall have the power to institute and maintain in the name of the City of Cornelia any and all such enforcement proceedings. (Ord. No. 11-10-03, § 19, 12-7-2010)

div.head: Chapter 33 - MOTION PICTURE, TELEVISION AND PHOTOGRAPHIC PRODUCTION
div.p: Sec. 33-1. - Motion picture, television and photographic production ordinance. (a) Permit required. No person shall use any public or private property, building, facility, or residence for producing, taking, or making any motion picture, television production, or photographic production without first applying for and receiving a city filming permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. (b) Exceptions. Regulations by this article shall not apply to: (1) Amateur photographers. (2) Reporters or cameramen in the employ of a newspaper, news service, radio, or television broadcasting station engaged in on-the-spot broadcasting, reporting, or photographing of news of general public interest. The exception is not to include magazine or documentary programs. (3) Productions which are conducted by the city or any city board or commission. (c) Permit administrator. The city manager is hereby appointed as the permit administrator and shall issue permits as provided for in this article. (d) Application for permit. (1) Any person desiring a permit under the provisions of this article shall make application on the approved form provided by the city. The form must be signed and accompanied by all required fees, deposits, hold harmless agreement and insurance certificates required by this article before any permit will be considered for approval. (2) Filming permit applications shall be submitted at least five working days prior to the date on which such person desires to conduct an activity for which a permit is required. (e) Issuance of permits; conditions; appeals. (1) The city manager shall issue a permit as provided for in this article, when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may be otherwise obtained, he finds that: a. The conduct of such activity will not unduly interfere with traffic or pedestrian movement or endanger public safety and that no streets will be completely closed to traffic for an unreasonable period of time. Seventy-two hours' advance notice of any street closure request shall be provided. b. The conduct of such activity will not unduly interfere with normal government or city operations, threaten to result in damage or detriment to public property, or result in damage or detriment to public property, or result in the city incurring costs or expenditures in either money or personnel not reimbursed in advance by the applicant. c. At the determination of the city manager that such activity will not constitute a fire hazard or any other type of hazard and all safety precautions will be taken as determined necessary by the city manager. (2) The decision of the city manager to issue, conditionally issue, or deny a permit shall be final unless appealed in writing within five working days of the decision to the city commission. (3) The city commission shall render a decision to issue, conditionally issue, or uphold the denial of a permit at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city commission. The decision of the city commission will be final. (f) Bond, issuance, hold harmless and indemnification. (1) As a condition of issuing such a permit, the applicant shall furnish a bond, insurance or both in the amount to be determined by the city manager, but in no event an amount less than $500,000.00, to protect the city against claims of third persons for personal injury, wrongful death and property damage and to indemnify the city for damage to city property arising out of the permittee's activities. (2) A minimum of $5,000,000.00 of such bond, general liability insurance coverage or both shall be required in the event aircraft, helicopters, pyrotechnics or automobile chase scenes are used in activity. Such insurance shall be evidenced by the standard general liability special endorsement from mandated by this article. The city shall be listed as additional insured and the applicant shall have primary coverage. (3) The applicant shall execute an indemnity and hold harmless agreement as provided by the city prior to the issuance of any permit that shall hold the city harmless against any claims, liability or judgments arising out of the permittee's activities. (g) Suspension or revocation of permit. The city manager shall have the authority, after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, to suspend or revoke any permit issued hereunder, where the terms and conditions of said permit have been violated or ignored, including the timely payment of all required fees and deposits, or suspend or revoke any permit where the public safety or welfare is endangered by the permitted activity. Provided, however, that whenever there is an imminent danger to the public health, safety or welfare from activities conducted by the permittee to the extent that immediate action is necessary to protect the public, the city manager shall have the authority to suspend a permit pending a hearing. (h) Fees and costs of additional services. Each application shall be accompanied by the following nonrefundable fees: (1) A processing fee in the amount of $150.00 will be submitted to the city at the time of application. (2) Upon approval of an application for a city filming permit, the city manager shall provide the applicant with a statement of estimated cost of providing police, public works, and other city employees and services for public safety for the production. The cost of such services shall be paid to the city prior to the conducting of a production. The amount of such fees shall be based on the city's actual cost of providing the required number of police and other city employees and services necessary to ensure the safety of both the participants of the production and the community. (3) If the actual cost of public services for the production is less than the estimated cost pursuant to subsection (h)(2) of this section, the permittee shall promptly be refunded the difference by the city. If the actual cost for public services is more than the estimated cost pursuant to subsection (h)(2) of this section the difference shall become due and payable to the city immediately upon the permittee's receipt of a statement of actual costs by the city. (4) All fees may be waived by the city manager for wholly charitable or educational purposes and from which no profit is derived, either directly or indirectly. Tax exempt and nonprofit organizations must qualify under Section 501(c)(3) of the United States Internal Revenue Code, and proof of such status must be provided to the city in order for said fees to be waived by the city. (i) Regulations and conditions. (1) The applicant shall: a. Maintain a copy of the production permit on-site at all times. b. Comply with any and all conditions or restrictions the city may impose as a condition to issuing a permit. No changes to the conditions or restrictions shall be made without the written approval of the city manager. c. Have nonexclusive use of facilities and public right-of-way unless otherwise granted in writing. d. Provide advanced notification of 48 hours in a form approved by the city manager to adjacent properties for any production. e. Comply with the City of Cornelia Noise Ordinance. (2) The city manager may promulgate and enforce additional regulations as necessary and appropriate in the implementation and enforcement of this article. (j) Filming on private property. (1) An applicant is required to obtain the property owner's permission, consent, and/or lease for the use of property not owned or controlled by the city. Written permission of the property owner must be presented at the time of the permit application. (2) An applicant is required to minimize interference with the normal activities of a neighborhood or commercial area, including access to private or public property. (k) Filming at city facilities or on the public right-of-way. In the event that the applicant desires to locate their production event at a facility owned or managed by the city or on the public right-of-way, the city shall charge a daily fee in an amount determined by the city manager not to exceed $1,000.00 per day. If an existing facility charge has been established by the city at a facility owned or managed by the city, that fee will be charged to the applicant. (l) Traffic control. The city retains the right and the authority to regulate traffic and require vehicles to be moved or towed at the owner's expense in order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the community. (m) Faithful performance bond; clean up and restoration. To ensure the clean up and restoration of any site on public property or public right-of-way used by the permittee within the city limits, said permittee may be required to post a refundable faithful performance bond (amount to be determined by the city manager) at the time the application is submitted. Upon completion of the production and upon the finding by the city that the site has been satisfactorily cleaned up and restored, the bond may be returned to the permittee. (Ord. No. 07-12-01, 8-7-2012) Sec. 33-2. - Production or filming for adult entertainment. Any production or filming for the purposes of adult entertainment is subject to chapter 4 of the Municipal Code of the City of Cornelia entitled "Adult Entertainment", and must meet the requirements of said ordinance prior to the issuance of any permit. (Ord. No. 07-12-01, 8-7-2012) Sec. 33-3. - [Codification.] The ordinace from which this chapter derives shall be codified in a manner consistent with the laws of the State of Georgia. (Ord. No. 07-12-01, 8-7-2012) Sec. 33-4. - [Validity; severability.] (a) It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that all sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this chapter are upon their enactment, believed by the city commission to be fully valid, enforceable and constitutional. (b) It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, each and every section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is severable from every other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter. It is further declared to be the intention of the city commission that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, no section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is mutually dependent upon any other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter. (c) In the event that any section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter shall, for any reason whatsoever, be declared invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, it is the express intent of the city commission that such invalidity, unconstitutionally or unenforceability shall, to the greatest extent allowed by law, not render invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable any of the remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases of this chapter and that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, all remaining sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, or phrases of this chapter shall remain valid, constitutional, enforceable, and of full force and effect. (Ord. No. 07-12-01, 8-7-2012) Sec. 33-5. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. Except as otherwise provided herein, all ordinance or parts of ordinances in conflict with this chapter are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 07-12-01, 8-7-2012) Sec. 33-6. - Effective date. The ordinance from which this chapter derives shall become effective upon its adoption. (Ord. No. 07-12-01, 8-7-2012)

div.head: Chapter 34 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Constitutional powers regarding parks, recreational areas, programs, and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, III(a)(5); municipal authority to own, operate and maintain parks, recreational facilities, and streets, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3.
Sec. 34-1. - Closing of park properties during certain hours. The city parks on Chattahoochee Street, Farlinger Street, Martin Luther King Drive, Oak Street, and Waste Water Treatment Plant Road (off Old Cleveland Road), as well as the city park property fronting on Wyly Street, LaVista Lane and Chase Road, excluding the Community House and its driveways, parking areas and grounds, Parkway Drive and Parkway Circle shall be closed to all persons other than city personnel in the performance of their duties between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following day. With the exception of the Community House and its driveways, parking areas and grounds, it shall be unlawful for any person other than city personnel in the performance of their duties to enter or be upon any city park property between the aforesaid hours. (Prior Code, § 34-1) Sec. 34-2. - Use of tennis courts. The two tennis courts in the city park which have no nets and are no longer maintained for the purpose of playing tennis may be used as a general play area. Use of the other two tennis courts in the city park, the two tennis courts on Oak Street and the tennis court on Farlinger Street for any purpose other than playing tennis or tennis instruction is prohibited, and, with the exception of city personnel in the performance of their duties, no one shall at any time be on such tennis courts while wearing footwear other than tennis shoes or for any purpose other than playing tennis or tennis instruction. (Prior Code, § 34-2) Sec. 34-3. - Violations and penalties. A violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 34-3)

div.head: Chapter 38 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to provide for garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const., art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); local solid waste management plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20; creation of municipal solid waste management authority, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-53; prohibition against public littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-43 et seq.; no limitation on municipal authority to declare nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.9; exemption as to individual disposing of household waste onto own land, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.10; adoption of ordinances to enforce nuisance provisions, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.
Sec. 38-1. - Unlawful deposit of trash, leaves, etc.—Public streets. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, dump, place or throw any garbage, trash, paper, brush, leaves, automobile parts, cigarette butts, debris or refuse of any kind on any public street or sidewalk of the city. (Prior Code, § 19-1) Sec. 38-2. - Same—Private property. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any real estate within the corporate limits of the city to cause or allow garbage, trash, paper, brush, leaves, automobile parts, debris or refuse to be dumped or to accumulate on such real estate in such quantity or for such period of time as to be detrimental to the health or general welfare of the citizens of the city. (Prior Code, § 19-2) Sec. 38-3. - Same—By tenant. It shall be unlawful for a tenant in possession of any real estate within the corporate limits of the city to cause or allow garbage, trash, paper, brush, leaves, automobile parts, debris or refuse to be dumped or to accumulate on such real estate in such quantity or for such period of time as to be detrimental to the health or general welfare of the citizens of the city. (Prior Code, § 19-3) Sec. 38-4. - Same—By business establishment. It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any business establishment within the corporate limits of the city to cause or allow garbage, trash or refuse to accumulate on or adjacent to the premises of such business establishment or on the public sidewalks or streets of the city in such quantity or for such period of time as to be detrimental to the health or general welfare of the citizens of the city. (Prior Code, § 19-4) Sec. 38-5. - Garbage and refuse collection and removal. (a) Residential garbage. Resulting from and necessitated by a tipping fee imposed and assessed by the county board of commissioners for disposal of solid waste at the county landfill, a fee for the collection and removal of garbage shall be charged for each residence in the city, whether a single-family dwelling, a living unit in a multi-housing structure such as an apartment or townhouse, a mobile home, or other place of residence, with the person responsible for water furnished to a residence also being responsible for this fee and billed therefore each month with the billing of water. (b) Refuse removal. There shall be no additional charge for the routine removal of residential refuse or refuse of businesses which pay a monthly fee. The city will remove such items as appliances, furniture, and tires for a fee to be determined by the city manager. Removal of either business or residential refuse in such quantity that requires a special trip to the county landfill by a city truck will be provided for a fee, and such amount will be billed a fee to be determined by the city manager with the requester's next monthly bill. To obtain this service, a business or resident may call city hall and request a truck to be sent to a specific location in the city. When the truck has been loaded, which shall have been done overnight or over the weekend by the requester, a city employee will remove the truck and deliver its load to the county landfill. (c) Excess garbage removal. At any time when there is more waste than will fit within the allowed 96-gallon container then the customer shall be assessed a removal fee to be determined by the city manager. (Prior Code, § 19-5(A)—(C); Ord. No. 11-05-01, § 1, 12-6-2005; Ord. No. 10-09-02, 11-3-2009; Ord. No. 11-17-01, 12-5-2017) Sec. 38-6. - Size of garbage cans. No can or other containers with a capacity in excess of 96 gallons, shall be used by any person within the corporate limits of the city for purpose of depositing and storing garbage, trash and refuse therein to be collected and removed by employees of the city. Each resident may use the city-issued 96 gallon container or three containers not more than 32 gallons each. (Prior Code, § 19-6; Ord. No. 10-09-02, 11-3-2009) Sec. 38-7. - Garbage cans to be kept covered. (a) The owners of all cans or other containers used within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of depositing and storing garbage, trash and refuse therein shall provide lids or other suitable covers therefor, and such cans and other containers shall be kept covered and closed at all times by the owners of such except when garbage, trash or other refuse is actually being deposited therein. (b) Garbage cans may be placed on the city right-of-way 24 hours in advance of scheduled pickup and must be removed from the right-of-way within 24 hours of pickup. (Prior Code, § 19-7; Ord. No. 11-17-01, 12-5-2017) Sec. 38-8. - Violation and penalty. A violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punishable as provided by section 1-12. (Prior Code, § 19-8) Sec. 38-9. - Refuse in creeks and waterways. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow garbage, trash, paper, brush, trees, grass trimmings, automobile parts, old appliances, scrap metal, roofing or other construction material or other similar debris, including cigarette butts, to be deposited into any stream, creek, waterway or stormwater drainage system within the city limits. (Prior Code, § 19-9) Sec. 38-10. - Prohibited items. (a) It shall be unlawful to deposit the following items in a garbage can to be removed by the city. Such items will not be removed: (1) Ammunition. (2) Auto parts. (3) Bricks. (4) Concrete. (5) Dirt. (6) Flammables. (7) Limbs over four inches in diameter. (8) Motor oil. (9) Stumps. (10) Pesticides. (11) Shingles. (12) Anti-freeze. (b) Paint cans will be removed if they are empty or in non-liquid form. Paint cans that still have paint in liquid form shall be filled with dirt, sand, or sawdust. (Ord. No. 11-17-01, 12-5-2017) Sec. 38-11. - Severability. If any section, clause, sentence or phrase of the ordinance from which this chapter derives is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way effect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 10-09-02, 11-3-2009) Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-17-01, adopted Dec. 5, 2017, added provisions to the Code to be included as § 38-10. For purposes of classification, and at the editor's discretion former §§ 38-10, 38-11, have been renumbered as §§ 38-11, 38-12. Sec. 38-12. - Repealer clause. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with the ordinance from which this chapter derives are hereby repealed. (Ord. No. 10-09-02, 11-3-2009) Editor's note— See the editor's note following § 38-11.

div.head: Chapter 40 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal power to develop, store, treat, purify, and distribute water, Ga. Const. art.
